       5             : /*         888    888    888       88b 888  888 888 888 888 d888  88b        */
       6             : /*         888    888    888  o88^o888 888  888 "88888" 888 8888oo888        */
       7             : /*         888    888    888 C888  888 888  888  /      888 q888             */
       8             : /*         888    888    888  "88o^888 888  888 Cb      888  "88oooo"        */

      12             : /*  (triangle.c)                                                             */
      13             : /*                                                                           */

      21             : /*  jrs@cs.berkeley.edu                                                      */
      22             : /*                                                                           */
      23             : /*  This program may be freely redistributed under the condition that the    */
      24             : /*    copyright notices (including this entire header and the copyright      */
      25             : /*    notice printed when the `-h' switch is selected) are not removed, and  */
      26             : /*    no compensation is received.  Private, research, and institutional     */
      27             : /*    use is free.  You may distribute modified versions of this code UNDER  */
      28             : /*    THE CONDITION THAT THIS CODE AND ANY MODIFICATIONS MADE TO IT IN THE   */
      29             : /*    SAME FILE REMAIN UNDER COPYRIGHT OF THE ORIGINAL AUTHOR, BOTH SOURCE   */
      30             : /*    AND OBJECT CODE ARE MADE FREELY AVAILABLE WITHOUT CHARGE, AND CLEAR    */
      31             : /*    NOTICE IS GIVEN OF THE MODIFICATIONS.  Distribution of this code as    */
      32             : /*    part of a commercial system is permissible ONLY BY DIRECT ARRANGEMENT  */
      33             : /*    WITH THE AUTHOR.  (If you are not directly supplying this code to a    */
      34             : /*    customer, and you are instead telling them how they can obtain it for  */
      35             : /*    free, then you are not required to make any arrangement with me.)      */
      36             : /*                                                                           */
      37             : /*  Hypertext instructions for Triangle are available on the Web at          */
      38             : /*                                                                           */
      39             : /*      http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~quake/triangle.html                           */
      40             : /*                                                                           */
      41             : /*  Disclaimer:  Neither I nor Carnegie Mellon warrant this code in any way  */
      42             : /*    whatsoever.  This code is provided "as-is".  Use at your own risk.     */
      43             : /*                                                                           */
      44             : /*  Some of the references listed below are marked with an asterisk.  [*]    */
      45             : /*    These references are available for downloading from the Web page       */
      46             : /*                                                                           */
      47             : /*      http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~quake/triangle.research.html                  */
      48             : /*                                                                           */
      49             : /*  Three papers discussing aspects of Triangle are available.  A short      */
      50             : /*    overview appears in "Triangle:  Engineering a 2D Quality Mesh          */
      51             : /*    Generator and Delaunay Triangulator," in Applied Computational         */
      52             : /*    Geometry:  Towards Geometric Engineering, Ming C. Lin and Dinesh       */
      53             : /*    Manocha, editors, Lecture Notes in Computer Science volume 1148,       */
      54             : /*    pages 203-222, Springer-Verlag, Berlin, May 1996 (from the First ACM   */
      55             : /*    Workshop on Applied Computational Geometry).  [*]                      */
      56             : /*                                                                           */
      57             : /*    The algorithms are discussed in the greatest detail in "Delaunay       */
      58             : /*    Refinement Algorithms for Triangular Mesh Generation," Computational   */
      59             : /*    Geometry:  Theory and Applications 22(1-3):21-74, May 2002.  [*]       */
      60             : /*                                                                           */
      61             : /*    More detail about the data structures may be found in my dissertation: */
      62             : /*    "Delaunay Refinement Mesh Generation," Ph.D. thesis, Technical Report  */
      63             : /*    CMU-CS-97-137, School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University, */
      64             : /*    Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 18 May 1997.  [*]                            */
      65             : /*                                                                           */
      66             : /*  Triangle was created as part of the Quake Project in the School of       */
      67             : /*    Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.  For further           */
      68             : /*    information, see Hesheng Bao, Jacobo Bielak, Omar Ghattas, Loukas F.   */
      69             : /*    Kallivokas, David R. O'Hallaron, Jonathan R. Shewchuk, and Jifeng Xu,  */
      70             : /*    "Large-scale Simulation of Elastic Wave Propagation in Heterogeneous   */
      71             : /*    Media on Parallel Computers," Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics    */
      72             : /*    and Engineering 152(1-2):85-102, 22 January 1998.                      */
      73             : /*                                                                           */
      74             : /*  Triangle's Delaunay refinement algorithm for quality mesh generation is  */
      75             : /*    a hybrid of one due to Jim Ruppert, "A Delaunay Refinement Algorithm   */
      76             : /*    for Quality 2-Dimensional Mesh Generation," Journal of Algorithms      */
      77             : /*    18(3):548-585, May 1995 [*], and one due to L. Paul Chew, "Guaranteed- */
      78             : /*    Quality Mesh Generation for Curved Surfaces," Proceedings of the Ninth */
      79             : /*    Annual Symposium on Computational Geometry (San Diego, California),    */
      80             : /*    pages 274-280, Association for Computing Machinery, May 1993,          */
      81             : /*    http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=161150 .                         */
      82             : /*                                                                           */
      83             : /*  The Delaunay refinement algorithm has been modified so that it meshes    */
      84             : /*    domains with small input angles well, as described in Gary L. Miller,  */
      85             : /*    Steven E. Pav, and Noel J. Walkington, "When and Why Ruppert's         */
      86             : /*    Algorithm Works," Twelfth International Meshing Roundtable, pages      */
      87             : /*    91-102, Sandia National Laboratories, September 2003.  [*]             */
      88             : /*                                                                           */
      89             : /*  My implementation of the divide-and-conquer and incremental Delaunay     */
      90             : /*    triangulation algorithms follows closely the presentation of Guibas    */
      91             : /*    and Stolfi, even though I use a triangle-based data structure instead  */
      92             : /*    of their quad-edge data structure.  (In fact, I originally implemented */
      93             : /*    Triangle using the quad-edge data structure, but the switch to a       */
      94             : /*    triangle-based data structure sped Triangle by a factor of two.)  The  */
      95             : /*    mesh manipulation primitives and the two aforementioned Delaunay       */
      96             : /*    triangulation algorithms are described by Leonidas J. Guibas and Jorge */
      97             : /*    Stolfi, "Primitives for the Manipulation of General Subdivisions and   */
      98             : /*    the Computation of Voronoi Diagrams," ACM Transactions on Graphics     */
      99             : /*    4(2):74-123, April 1985, http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=282923 .*/
     100             : /*                                                                           */
     101             : /*  Their O(n log n) divide-and-conquer algorithm is adapted from Der-Tsai   */
     102             : /*    Lee and Bruce J. Schachter, "Two Algorithms for Constructing the       */
     103             : /*    Delaunay Triangulation," International Journal of Computer and         */
     104             : /*    Information Science 9(3):219-242, 1980.  Triangle's improvement of the */
     105             : /*    divide-and-conquer algorithm by alternating between vertical and       */
     106             : /*    horizontal cuts was introduced by Rex A. Dwyer, "A Faster Divide-and-  */
     107             : /*    Conquer Algorithm for Constructing Delaunay Triangulations,"           */
     108             : /*    Algorithmica 2(2):137-151, 1987.                                       */
     109             : /*                                                                           */
     110             : /*  The incremental insertion algorithm was first proposed by C. L. Lawson,  */
     111             : /*    "Software for C1 Surface Interpolation," in Mathematical Software III, */
     112             : /*    John R. Rice, editor, Academic Press, New York, pp. 161-194, 1977.     */
     113             : /*    For point location, I use the algorithm of Ernst P. Mucke, Isaac       */
     114             : /*    Saias, and Binhai Zhu, "Fast Randomized Point Location Without         */
     115             : /*    Preprocessing in Two- and Three-Dimensional Delaunay Triangulations,"  */
     116             : /*    Proceedings of the Twelfth Annual Symposium on Computational Geometry, */
     117             : /*    ACM, May 1996.  [*]  If I were to randomize the order of vertex        */
     118             : /*    insertion (I currently don't bother), their result combined with the   */
     119             : /*    result of Kenneth L. Clarkson and Peter W. Shor, "Applications of      */
     120             : /*    Random Sampling in Computational Geometry II," Discrete &              */
     121             : /*    Computational Geometry 4(1):387-421, 1989, would yield an expected     */
     122             : /*    O(n^{4/3}) bound on running time.                                      */
     123             : /*                                                                           */
     124             : /*  The O(n log n) sweepline Delaunay triangulation algorithm is taken from  */
     125             : /*    Steven Fortune, "A Sweepline Algorithm for Voronoi Diagrams",          */
     126             : /*    Algorithmica 2(2):153-174, 1987.  A random sample of edges on the      */
     127             : /*    boundary of the triangulation are maintained in a splay tree for the   */
     128             : /*    purpose of point location.  Splay trees are described by Daniel        */
     129             : /*    Dominic Sleator and Robert Endre Tarjan, "Self-Adjusting Binary Search */
     130             : /*    Trees," Journal of the ACM 32(3):652-686, July 1985,                   */
     131             : /*    http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3835 .                           */
     132             : /*                                                                           */
     133             : /*  The algorithms for exact computation of the signs of determinants are    */
     134             : /*    described in Jonathan Richard Shewchuk, "Adaptive Precision Floating-  */
     135             : /*    Point Arithmetic and Fast Robust Geometric Predicates," Discrete &     */
     136             : /*    Computational Geometry 18(3):305-363, October 1997.  (Also available   */
     137             : /*    as Technical Report CMU-CS-96-140, School of Computer Science,         */
     138             : /*    Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, May 1996.)  [*]  */
     139             : /*    An abbreviated version appears as Jonathan Richard Shewchuk, "Robust   */
     140             : /*    Adaptive Floating-Point Geometric Predicates," Proceedings of the      */
     141             : /*    Twelfth Annual Symposium on Computational Geometry, ACM, May 1996. [*] */
     142             : /*    Many of the ideas for my exact arithmetic routines originate with      */
     143             : /*    Douglas M. Priest, "Algorithms for Arbitrary Precision Floating Point  */
     144             : /*    Arithmetic," Tenth Symposium on Computer Arithmetic, pp. 132-143, IEEE */
     145             : /*    Computer Society Press, 1991.  [*]  Many of the ideas for the correct  */
     146             : /*    evaluation of the signs of determinants are taken from Steven Fortune  */
     147             : /*    and Christopher J. Van Wyk, "Efficient Exact Arithmetic for Computa-   */
     148             : /*    tional Geometry," Proceedings of the Ninth Annual Symposium on         */
     149             : /*    Computational Geometry, ACM, pp. 163-172, May 1993, and from Steven    */
     150             : /*    Fortune, "Numerical Stability of Algorithms for 2D Delaunay Triangu-   */
     151             : /*    lations," International Journal of Computational Geometry & Applica-   */
     152             : /*    tions 5(1-2):193-213, March-June 1995.                                 */
     153             : /*                                                                           */
     154             : /*  The method of inserting new vertices off-center (not precisely at the    */
     155             : /*    circumcenter of every poor-quality triangle) is from Alper Ungor,      */
     156             : /*    "Off-centers:  A New Type of Steiner Points for Computing Size-Optimal */
     157             : /*    Quality-Guaranteed Delaunay Triangulations," Proceedings of LATIN      */
     158             : /*    2004 (Buenos Aires, Argentina), April 2004.                            */
     159             : /*                                                                           */
     160             : /*  For definitions of and results involving Delaunay triangulations,        */
     161             : /*    constrained and conforming versions thereof, and other aspects of      */
     162             : /*    triangular mesh generation, see the excellent survey by Marshall Bern  */
     163             : /*    and David Eppstein, "Mesh Generation and Optimal Triangulation," in    */
     164             : /*    Computing and Euclidean Geometry, Ding-Zhu Du and Frank Hwang,         */
     165             : /*    editors, World Scientific, Singapore, pp. 23-90, 1992.  [*]            */
     166             : /*                                                                           */
     167             : /*  The time for incrementally adding PSLG (planar straight line graph)      */
     168             : /*    segments to create a constrained Delaunay triangulation is probably    */
     169             : /*    O(t^2) per segment in the worst case and O(t) per segment in the       */
     170             : /*    common case, where t is the number of triangles that intersect the     */
     171             : /*    segment before it is inserted.  This doesn't count point location,     */
     172             : /*    which can be much more expensive.  I could improve this to O(d log d)  */
     173             : /*    time, but d is usually quite small, so it's not worth the bother.      */
     174             : /*    (This note does not apply when the -s switch is used, invoking a       */
     175             : /*    different method is used to insert segments.)                          */
     176             : /*                                                                           */
     177             : /*  The time for deleting a vertex from a Delaunay triangulation is O(d^2)   */
     178             : /*    in the worst case and O(d) in the common case, where d is the degree   */
     179             : /*    of the vertex being deleted.  I could improve this to O(d log d) time, */
     180             : /*    but d is usually quite small, so it's not worth the bother.            */
     181             : /*                                                                           */
     182             : /*  Ruppert's Delaunay refinement algorithm typically generates triangles    */
     183             : /*    at a linear rate (constant time per triangle) after the initial        */
     184             : /*    triangulation is formed.  There may be pathological cases where        */
     185             : /*    quadratic time is required, but these never arise in practice.         */
     186             : /*                                                                           */
     187             : /*  The geometric predicates (circumcenter calculations, segment             */
     188             : /*    intersection formulae, etc.) appear in my "Lecture Notes on Geometric  */
     189             : /*    Robustness" at http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~jrs/mesh .                  */
     190             : /*                                                                           */
     191             : /*  If you make any improvements to this code, please please please let me   */
     192             : /*    know, so that I may obtain the improvements.  Even if you don't change */
     193             : /*    the code, I'd still love to hear what it's being used for.             */
     194             : /*                                                                           */
     195             : /*****************************************************************************/
     196             : 
     197             : /* For single precision (which will save some memory and reduce paging),     */
     198             : /*   define the symbol SINGLE by using the -DSINGLE compiler switch or by    */
     199             : /*   writing "#define SINGLE" below.                                         */
     200             : /*                                                                           */
     201             : /* For double precision (which will allow you to refine meshes to a smaller  */
     202             : /*   edge length), leave SINGLE undefined.                                   */
     203             : /*                                                                           */
     204             : /* Double precision uses more memory, but improves the resolution of the     */
     205             : /*   meshes you can generate with Triangle.  It also reduces the likelihood  */
     206             : /*   of a floating exception due to overflow.  Finally, it is much faster    */
     207             : /*   than single precision on 64-bit architectures like the DEC Alpha.  I    */
     208             : /*   recommend double precision unless you want to generate a mesh for which */
     209             : /*   you do not have enough memory.                                          */
     210             : 
     211             : /* #define SINGLE */
     212             : 
     213             : #ifdef SINGLE
     214             : #define REAL float
     215             : #else /* not SINGLE */
     216             : #define REAL double
     217             : #endif /* not SINGLE */
     218             : 
     219             : /* If yours is not a Unix system, define the NO_TIMER compiler switch to     */
     220             : /*   remove the Unix-specific timing code.                                   */
     221             : 
     222             : /* #define NO_TIMER */
     223             : 
     224             : /* To insert lots of self-checks for internal errors, define the SELF_CHECK  */
     225             : /*   symbol.  This will slow down the program significantly.  It is best to  */
     226             : /*   define the symbol using the -DSELF_CHECK compiler switch, but you could */
     227             : /*   write "#define SELF_CHECK" below.  If you are modifying this code, I    */
     228             : /*   recommend you turn self-checks on until your work is debugged.          */
     229             : 
     230             : /* #define SELF_CHECK */
     231             : 
     232             : /* To compile Triangle as a callable object library (triangle.o), define the */
     233             : /*   TRILIBRARY symbol.  Read the file triangle.h for details on how to call */
     234             : /*   the procedure triangulate() that results.                               */
     235             : 
     236             : /* #define TRILIBRARY */
     237             : 
     238             : /* It is possible to generate a smaller version of Triangle using one or     */
     239             : /*   both of the following symbols.  Define the REDUCED symbol to eliminate  */
     240             : /*   all features that are primarily of research interest; specifically, the */
     241             : /*   -i, -F, -s, and -C switches.  Define the CDT_ONLY symbol to eliminate   */
     242             : /*   all meshing algorithms above and beyond constrained Delaunay            */
     243             : /*   triangulation; specifically, the -r, -q, -a, -u, -D, -S, and -s         */
     244             : /*   switches.  These reductions are most likely to be useful when           */
     245             : /*   generating an object library (triangle.o) by defining the TRILIBRARY    */
     246             : /*   symbol.                                                                 */
     247             : 
     248             : /* #define REDUCED */
     249             : /* #define CDT_ONLY */
     250             : 
     251             : /* On some machines, my exact arithmetic routines might be defeated by the   */
     252             : /*   use of internal extended precision floating-point registers.  The best  */
     253             : /*   way to solve this problem is to set the floating-point registers to use */
     254             : /*   single or double precision internally.  On 80x86 processors, this may   */
     255             : /*   be accomplished by setting the CPU86 symbol for the Microsoft C         */
     256             : /*   compiler, or the LINUX symbol for the gcc compiler running on Linux.    */
     257             : /*                                                                           */
     258             : /* An inferior solution is to declare certain values as `volatile', thus     */
     259             : /*   forcing them to be stored to memory and rounded off.  Unfortunately,    */
     260             : /*   this solution might slow Triangle down quite a bit.  To use volatile    */
     261             : /*   values, write "#define INEXACT volatile" below.  Normally, however,     */
     262             : /*   INEXACT should be defined to be nothing.  ("#define INEXACT".)          */
     263             : /*                                                                           */
     264             : /* For more discussion, see http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~quake/robust.pc.html .    */
     265             : /*   For yet more discussion, see Section 5 of my paper, "Adaptive Precision */
     266             : /*   Floating-Point Arithmetic and Fast Robust Geometric Predicates" (also   */
     267             : /*   available as Section 6.6 of my dissertation).                           */
     268             : 
     269             : /* #define CPU86 */
     270             : /* #define LINUX */
     271             : 
     272             : #define INEXACT /* Nothing */
     273             : /* #define INEXACT volatile */
     274             : 
     275             : /* Maximum number of characters in a file name (including the null).         */
     276             : 
     277             : #define FILENAMESIZE 2048
     278             : 
     279             : /* Maximum number of characters in a line read from a file (including the    */
     280             : /*   null).                                                                  */
     281             : 
     282             : #define INPUTLINESIZE 1024
     283             : 
     284             : /* For efficiency, a variety of data structures are allocated in bulk.  The  */
     285             : /*   following constants determine how many of each structure is allocated   */
     286             : /*   at once.                                                                */
     287             : 
     288             : #define TRIPERBLOCK 4092           /* Number of triangles allocated at once. */
     289             : #define SUBSEGPERBLOCK 508       /* Number of subsegments allocated at once. */
     290             : #define VERTEXPERBLOCK 4092         /* Number of vertices allocated at once. */
     291             : #define VIRUSPERBLOCK 1020   /* Number of virus triangles allocated at once. */
     292             : /* Number of encroached subsegments allocated at once. */
     293             : #define BADSUBSEGPERBLOCK 252
     294             : /* Number of skinny triangles allocated at once. */
     295             : #define BADTRIPERBLOCK 4092
     296             : /* Number of flipped triangles allocated at once. */
     297             : #define FLIPSTACKERPERBLOCK 252
     298             : /* Number of splay tree nodes allocated at once. */
     299             : #define SPLAYNODEPERBLOCK 508
     300             : 
     301             : /* The vertex types.   A DEADVERTEX has been deleted entirely.  An           */
     302             : /*   UNDEADVERTEX is not part of the mesh, but is written to the output      */
     303             : /*   .node file and affects the node indexing in the other output files.     */
     304             : 
     305             : #define INPUTVERTEX 0
     306             : #define SEGMENTVERTEX 1
     307             : #define FREEVERTEX 2
     308             : #define DEADVERTEX -32768
     309             : #define UNDEADVERTEX -32767
     310             : 
     311             : /* The next line is used to outsmart some very stupid compilers.  If your    */
     312             : /*   compiler is smarter, feel free to replace the "int" with "void".        */
     313             : /*   Not that it matters.                                                    */
     314             : 
     315             : #define VOID int
     316             : 
     317             : /* Two constants for algorithms based on random sampling.  Both constants    */
     318             : /*   have been chosen empirically to optimize their respective algorithms.   */
     319             : 
     320             : /* Used for the point location scheme of Mucke, Saias, and Zhu, to decide    */
     321             : /*   how large a random sample of triangles to inspect.                      */
     322             : 
     323             : #define SAMPLEFACTOR 11
     324             : 
     325             : /* Used in Fortune's sweepline Delaunay algorithm to determine what fraction */
     326             : /*   of boundary edges should be maintained in the splay tree for point      */
     327             : /*   location on the front.                                                  */
     328             : 
     329             : #define SAMPLERATE 10
     330             : 
     331             : /* A number that speaks for itself, every kissable digit.                    */
     332             : 
     333             : #define PI 3.141592653589793238462643383279502884197169399375105820974944592308
     334             : 
     335             : /* Another fave.                                                             */
     336             : 
     337             : #define SQUAREROOTTWO 1.4142135623730950488016887242096980785696718753769480732
     338             : 
     339             : /* And here's one for those of you who are intimidated by math.              */
     340             : 
     341             : #define ONETHIRD 0.333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333
     342             : 
     343             : #include <stdio.h>
     344             : #include <stdlib.h>
     345             : #include <string.h>
     346             : #include <stddef.h>
     347             : #include <math.h>
     348             : #ifndef NO_TIMER
     349             : #include <sys/time.h>
     350             : #endif /* not NO_TIMER */
     351             : #ifdef CPU86
     352             : #include <float.h>
     353             : #endif /* CPU86 */
     354             : #ifdef LINUX
     355             : #ifndef __APPLE__
     356             : #include <fpu_control.h>
     357             : #endif /* not APPLE */
     358             : #endif /* LINUX */
     359             : #ifdef TRILIBRARY
     360             : #include "triangle.h"
     361             : #endif /* TRILIBRARY */
     362             : 
     363             : /* A few forward declarations.                                               */
     364             : 
     365             : #ifndef TRILIBRARY
     366             : char *readline();
     367             : char *findfield();
     368             : #endif /* not TRILIBRARY */
     369             : 
     370             : /* Labels that signify the result of point location.  The result of a        */
     371             : /*   search indicates that the point falls in the interior of a triangle, on */
     372             : /*   an edge, on a vertex, or outside the mesh.                              */
     373             : 
     374             : enum locateresult {INTRIANGLE, ONEDGE, ONVERTEX, OUTSIDE};
     375             : 
     376             : /* Labels that signify the result of vertex insertion.  The result indicates */
     377             : /*   that the vertex was inserted with complete success, was inserted but    */
     378             : /*   encroaches upon a subsegment, was not inserted because it lies on a     */
     379             : /*   segment, or was not inserted because another vertex occupies the same   */
     380             : /*   location.                                                               */
     381             : 
     382             : enum insertvertexresult {SUCCESSFULVERTEX, ENCROACHINGVERTEX, VIOLATINGVERTEX,
     383             :                          DUPLICATEVERTEX};
     384             : 
     385             : /* Labels that signify the result of direction finding.  The result          */
     386             : /*   indicates that a segment connecting the two query points falls within   */
     387             : /*   the direction triangle, along the left edge of the direction triangle,  */
     388             : /*   or along the right edge of the direction triangle.                      */
     389             : 
     390             : enum finddirectionresult {WITHIN, LEFTCOLLINEAR, RIGHTCOLLINEAR};
     391             : 
     392             : /*****************************************************************************/
     393             : /*                                                                           */
     394             : /*  The basic mesh data structures                                           */
     395             : /*                                                                           */
     396             : /*  There are three:  vertices, triangles, and subsegments (abbreviated      */
     397             : /*  `subseg').  These three data structures, linked by pointers, comprise    */
     398             : /*  the mesh.  A vertex simply represents a mesh vertex and its properties.  */
     399             : /*  A triangle is a triangle.  A subsegment is a special data structure used */
     400             : /*  to represent an impenetrable edge of the mesh (perhaps on the outer      */
     401             : /*  boundary, on the boundary of a hole, or part of an internal boundary     */
     402             : /*  separating two triangulated regions).  Subsegments represent boundaries, */
     403             : /*  defined by the user, that triangles may not lie across.                  */
     404             : /*                                                                           */
     405             : /*  A triangle consists of a list of three vertices, a list of three         */
     406             : /*  adjoining triangles, a list of three adjoining subsegments (when         */
     407             : /*  segments exist), an arbitrary number of optional user-defined            */
     408             : /*  floating-point attributes, and an optional area constraint.  The latter  */
     409             : /*  is an upper bound on the permissible area of each triangle in a region,  */
     410             : /*  used for mesh refinement.                                                */
     411             : /*                                                                           */
     412             : /*  For a triangle on a boundary of the mesh, some or all of the neighboring */
     413             : /*  triangles may not be present.  For a triangle in the interior of the     */
     414             : /*  mesh, often no neighboring subsegments are present.  Such absent         */
     415             : /*  triangles and subsegments are never represented by NULL pointers; they   */
     416             : /*  are represented by two special records:  `dummytri', the triangle that   */
     417             : /*  fills "outer space", and `dummysub', the omnipresent subsegment.         */
     418             : /*  `dummytri' and `dummysub' are used for several reasons; for instance,    */
     419             : /*  they can be dereferenced and their contents examined without violating   */
     420             : /*  protected memory.                                                        */
     421             : /*                                                                           */
     422             : /*  However, it is important to understand that a triangle includes other    */
     423             : /*  information as well.  The pointers to adjoining vertices, triangles, and */
     424             : /*  subsegments are ordered in a way that indicates their geometric relation */
     425             : /*  to each other.  Furthermore, each of these pointers contains orientation */
     426             : /*  information.  Each pointer to an adjoining triangle indicates which face */
     427             : /*  of that triangle is contacted.  Similarly, each pointer to an adjoining  */
     428             : /*  subsegment indicates which side of that subsegment is contacted, and how */
     429             : /*  the subsegment is oriented relative to the triangle.                     */
     430             : /*                                                                           */
     431             : /*  The data structure representing a subsegment may be thought to be        */
     432             : /*  abutting the edge of one or two triangle data structures:  either        */
     433             : /*  sandwiched between two triangles, or resting against one triangle on an  */
     434             : /*  exterior boundary or hole boundary.                                      */
     435             : /*                                                                           */
     436             : /*  A subsegment consists of a list of four vertices--the vertices of the    */
     437             : /*  subsegment, and the vertices of the segment it is a part of--a list of   */
     438             : /*  two adjoining subsegments, and a list of two adjoining triangles.  One   */
     439             : /*  of the two adjoining triangles may not be present (though there should   */
     440             : /*  always be one), and neighboring subsegments might not be present.        */
     441             : /*  Subsegments also store a user-defined integer "boundary marker".         */
     442             : /*  Typically, this integer is used to indicate what boundary conditions are */
     443             : /*  to be applied at that location in a finite element simulation.           */
     444             : /*                                                                           */
     445             : /*  Like triangles, subsegments maintain information about the relative      */
     446             : /*  orientation of neighboring objects.                                      */
     447             : /*                                                                           */
     448             : /*  Vertices are relatively simple.  A vertex is a list of floating-point    */
     449             : /*  numbers, starting with the x, and y coordinates, followed by an          */
     450             : /*  arbitrary number of optional user-defined floating-point attributes,     */
     451             : /*  followed by an integer boundary marker.  During the segment insertion    */
     452             : /*  phase, there is also a pointer from each vertex to a triangle that may   */
     453             : /*  contain it.  Each pointer is not always correct, but when one is, it     */
     454             : /*  speeds up segment insertion.  These pointers are assigned values once    */
     455             : /*  at the beginning of the segment insertion phase, and are not used or     */
     456             : /*  updated except during this phase.  Edge flipping during segment          */
     457             : /*  insertion will render some of them incorrect.  Hence, don't rely upon    */
     458             : /*  them for anything.                                                       */
     459             : /*                                                                           */
     460             : /*  Other than the exception mentioned above, vertices have no information   */
     461             : /*  about what triangles, subfacets, or subsegments they are linked to.      */
     462             : /*                                                                           */
     463             : /*****************************************************************************/
     464             : 
     465             : /*****************************************************************************/
     466             : /*                                                                           */
     467             : /*  Handles                                                                  */
     468             : /*                                                                           */
     469             : /*  The oriented triangle (`otri') and oriented subsegment (`osub') data     */
     470             : /*  structures defined below do not themselves store any part of the mesh.   */
     471             : /*  The mesh itself is made of `triangle's, `subseg's, and `vertex's.        */
     472             : /*                                                                           */
     473             : /*  Oriented triangles and oriented subsegments will usually be referred to  */
     474             : /*  as "handles."  A handle is essentially a pointer into the mesh; it       */
     475             : /*  allows you to "hold" one particular part of the mesh.  Handles are used  */
     476             : /*  to specify the regions in which one is traversing and modifying the mesh.*/
     477             : /*  A single `triangle' may be held by many handles, or none at all.  (The   */
     478             : /*  latter case is not a memory leak, because the triangle is still          */
     479             : /*  connected to other triangles in the mesh.)                               */
     480             : /*                                                                           */
     481             : /*  An `otri' is a handle that holds a triangle.  It holds a specific edge   */
     482             : /*  of the triangle.  An `osub' is a handle that holds a subsegment.  It     */
     483             : /*  holds either the left or right side of the subsegment.                   */
     484             : /*                                                                           */
     485             : /*  Navigation about the mesh is accomplished through a set of mesh          */
     486             : /*  manipulation primitives, further below.  Many of these primitives take   */
     487             : /*  a handle and produce a new handle that holds the mesh near the first     */
     488             : /*  handle.  Other primitives take two handles and glue the corresponding    */
     489             : /*  parts of the mesh together.  The orientation of the handles is           */
     490             : /*  important.  For instance, when two triangles are glued together by the   */
     491             : /*  bond() primitive, they are glued at the edges on which the handles lie.  */
     492             : /*                                                                           */
     493             : /*  Because vertices have no information about which triangles they are      */
     494             : /*  attached to, I commonly represent a vertex by use of a handle whose      */
     495             : /*  origin is the vertex.  A single handle can simultaneously represent a    */
     496             : /*  triangle, an edge, and a vertex.                                         */
     497             : /*                                                                           */
     498             : /*****************************************************************************/
     499             : 
     500             : /* The triangle data structure.  Each triangle contains three pointers to    */
     501             : /*   adjoining triangles, plus three pointers to vertices, plus three        */
     502             : /*   pointers to subsegments (declared below; these pointers are usually     */
     503             : /*   `dummysub').  It may or may not also contain user-defined attributes    */
     504             : /*   and/or a floating-point "area constraint."  It may also contain extra   */
     505             : /*   pointers for nodes, when the user asks for high-order elements.         */
     506             : /*   Because the size and structure of a `triangle' is not decided until     */
     507             : /*   runtime, I haven't simply declared the type `triangle' as a struct.     */
     508             : 
     509             : typedef REAL **triangle;            /* Really:  typedef triangle *triangle   */
     510             : 
     511             : /* An oriented triangle:  includes a pointer to a triangle and orientation.  */
     512             : /*   The orientation denotes an edge of the triangle.  Hence, there are      */
     513             : /*   three possible orientations.  By convention, each edge always points    */
     514             : /*   counterclockwise about the corresponding triangle.                      */
     515             : 
     516             : struct otri {
     517             :   triangle *tri;
     518             :   int orient;                                         /* Ranges from 0 to 2. */
     519             : };
     520             : 
     521             : /* The subsegment data structure.  Each subsegment contains two pointers to  */
     522             : /*   adjoining subsegments, plus four pointers to vertices, plus two         */
     523             : /*   pointers to adjoining triangles, plus one boundary marker, plus one     */
     524             : /*   segment number.                                                         */
     525             : 
     526             : typedef REAL **subseg;                  /* Really:  typedef subseg *subseg   */
     527             : 
     528             : /* An oriented subsegment:  includes a pointer to a subsegment and an        */
     529             : /*   orientation.  The orientation denotes a side of the edge.  Hence, there */
     530             : /*   are two possible orientations.  By convention, the edge is always       */
     531             : /*   directed so that the "side" denoted is the right side of the edge.      */
     532             : 
     533             : struct osub {
     534             :   subseg *ss;
     535             :   int ssorient;                                       /* Ranges from 0 to 1. */
     536             : };
     537             : 
     538             : /* The vertex data structure.  Each vertex is actually an array of REALs.    */
     539             : /*   The number of REALs is unknown until runtime.  An integer boundary      */
     540             : /*   marker, and sometimes a pointer to a triangle, is appended after the    */
     541             : /*   REALs.                                                                  */
     542             : 
     543             : typedef REAL *vertex;
     544             : 
     545             : /* A queue used to store encroached subsegments.  Each subsegment's vertices */
     546             : /*   are stored so that we can check whether a subsegment is still the same. */
     547             : 
     548             : struct badsubseg {
     549             :   subseg encsubseg;                             /* An encroached subsegment. */
     550             :   vertex subsegorg, subsegdest;                         /* Its two vertices. */
     551             : };
     552             : 
     553             : /* A queue used to store bad triangles.  The key is the square of the cosine */
     554             : /*   of the smallest angle of the triangle.  Each triangle's vertices are    */
     555             : /*   stored so that one can check whether a triangle is still the same.      */
     556             : 
     557             : struct badtriang {
     558             :   triangle poortri;                       /* A skinny or too-large triangle. */
     559             :   REAL key;                             /* cos^2 of smallest (apical) angle. */
     560             :   vertex triangorg, triangdest, triangapex;           /* Its three vertices. */
     561             :   struct badtriang *nexttriang;             /* Pointer to next bad triangle. */
     562             : };
     563             : 
     564             : /* A stack of triangles flipped during the most recent vertex insertion.     */
     565             : /*   The stack is used to undo the vertex insertion if the vertex encroaches */
     566             : /*   upon a subsegment.                                                      */
     567             : 
     568             : struct flipstacker {
     569             :   triangle flippedtri;                       /* A recently flipped triangle. */
     570             :   struct flipstacker *prevflip;               /* Previous flip in the stack. */
     571             : };
     572             : 
     573             : /* A node in a heap used to store events for the sweepline Delaunay          */
     574             : /*   algorithm.  Nodes do not point directly to their parents or children in */
     575             : /*   the heap.  Instead, each node knows its position in the heap, and can   */
     576             : /*   look up its parent and children in a separate array.  The `eventptr'    */
     577             : /*   points either to a `vertex' or to a triangle (in encoded format, so     */
     578             : /*   that an orientation is included).  In the latter case, the origin of    */
     579             : /*   the oriented triangle is the apex of a "circle event" of the sweepline  */
     580             : /*   algorithm.  To distinguish site events from circle events, all circle   */
     581             : /*   events are given an invalid (smaller than `xmin') x-coordinate `xkey'.  */
     582             : 
     583             : struct event {
     584             :   REAL xkey, ykey;                              /* Coordinates of the event. */
     585             :   VOID *eventptr;      /* Can be a vertex or the location of a circle event. */
     586             :   int heapposition;              /* Marks this event's position in the heap. */
     587             : };
     588             : 
     589             : /* A node in the splay tree.  Each node holds an oriented ghost triangle     */
     590             : /*   that represents a boundary edge of the growing triangulation.  When a   */
     591             : /*   circle event covers two boundary edges with a triangle, so that they    */
     592             : /*   are no longer boundary edges, those edges are not immediately deleted   */
     593             : /*   from the tree; rather, they are lazily deleted when they are next       */
     594             : /*   encountered.  (Since only a random sample of boundary edges are kept    */
     595             : /*   in the tree, lazy deletion is faster.)  `keydest' is used to verify     */
     596             : /*   that a triangle is still the same as when it entered the splay tree; if */
     597             : /*   it has been rotated (due to a circle event), it no longer represents a  */
     598             : /*   boundary edge and should be deleted.                                    */
     599             : 
     600             : struct splaynode {
     601             :   struct otri keyedge;                     /* Lprev of an edge on the front. */
     602             :   vertex keydest;           /* Used to verify that splay node is still live. */
     603             :   struct splaynode *lchild, *rchild;              /* Children in splay tree. */
     604             : };
     605             : 
     606             : /* A type used to allocate memory.  firstblock is the first block of items.  */
     607             : /*   nowblock is the block from which items are currently being allocated.   */
     608             : /*   nextitem points to the next slab of free memory for an item.            */
     609             : /*   deaditemstack is the head of a linked list (stack) of deallocated items */
     610             : /*   that can be recycled.  unallocateditems is the number of items that     */
     611             : /*   remain to be allocated from nowblock.                                   */
     612             : /*                                                                           */
     613             : /* Traversal is the process of walking through the entire list of items, and */
     614             : /*   is separate from allocation.  Note that a traversal will visit items on */
     615             : /*   the "deaditemstack" stack as well as live items.  pathblock points to   */
     616             : /*   the block currently being traversed.  pathitem points to the next item  */
     617             : /*   to be traversed.  pathitemsleft is the number of items that remain to   */
     618             : /*   be traversed in pathblock.                                              */
     619             : /*                                                                           */
     620             : /* alignbytes determines how new records should be aligned in memory.        */
     621             : /*   itembytes is the length of a record in bytes (after rounding up).       */
     622             : /*   itemsperblock is the number of items allocated at once in a single      */
     623             : /*   block.  itemsfirstblock is the number of items in the first block,      */
     624             : /*   which can vary from the others.  items is the number of currently       */
     625             : /*   allocated items.  maxitems is the maximum number of items that have     */
     626             : /*   been allocated at once; it is the current number of items plus the      */
     627             : /*   number of records kept on deaditemstack.                                */
     628             : 
     629             : struct memorypool {
     630             :   VOID **firstblock, **nowblock;
     631             :   VOID *nextitem;
     632             :   VOID *deaditemstack;
     633             :   VOID **pathblock;
     634             :   VOID *pathitem;
     635             :   int alignbytes;
     636             :   int itembytes;
     637             :   int itemsperblock;
     638             :   int itemsfirstblock;
     639             :   ptrdiff_t  items, maxitems;
     640             :   int unallocateditems;
     641             :   int pathitemsleft;
     642             : };
     643             : 
     644             : 
     645             : /* Global constants.                                                         */
     646             : 
     647             : REAL splitter;       /* Used to split REAL factors for exact multiplication. */
     648             : REAL epsilon;                             /* Floating-point machine epsilon. */
     649             : REAL resulterrbound;
     650             : REAL ccwerrboundA, ccwerrboundB, ccwerrboundC;
     651             : REAL iccerrboundA, iccerrboundB, iccerrboundC;
     652             : REAL o3derrboundA, o3derrboundB, o3derrboundC;
     653             : 
     654             : /* Random number seed is not constant, but I've made it global anyway.       */
     655             : 
     656             : size_t randomseed;                     /* Current random number seed. */
     657             : 
     658             : 
     659             : /* Mesh data structure.  Triangle operates on only one mesh, but the mesh    */
     660             : /*   structure is used (instead of global variables) to allow reentrancy.    */
     661             : 
     662             : struct mesh {
     663             : 
     664             : /* Variables used to allocate memory for triangles, subsegments, vertices,   */
     665             : /*   viri (triangles being eaten), encroached segments, bad (skinny or too   */
     666             : /*   large) triangles, and splay tree nodes.                                 */
     667             : 
     668             :   struct memorypool triangles;
     669             :   struct memorypool subsegs;
     670             :   struct memorypool vertices;
     671             :   struct memorypool viri;
     672             :   struct memorypool badsubsegs;
     673             :   struct memorypool badtriangles;
     674             :   struct memorypool flipstackers;
     675             :   struct memorypool splaynodes;
     676             : 
     677             : /* Variables that maintain the bad triangle queues.  The queues are          */
     678             : /*   ordered from 4095 (highest priority) to 0 (lowest priority).            */
     679             : 
     680             :   struct badtriang *queuefront[4096];
     681             :   struct badtriang *queuetail[4096];
     682             :   int nextnonemptyq[4096];
     683             :   int firstnonemptyq;
     684             : 
     685             : /* Variable that maintains the stack of recently flipped triangles.          */
     686             : 
     687             :   struct flipstacker *lastflip;
     688             : 
     689             : /* Other variables. */
     690             : 
     691             :   REAL xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax;                            /* x and y bounds. */
     692             :   REAL xminextreme;      /* Nonexistent x value used as a flag in sweepline. */
     693             :   int invertices;                               /* Number of input vertices. */
     694             :   int inelements;                              /* Number of input triangles. */
     695             :   int insegments;                               /* Number of input segments. */
     696             :   int holes;                                       /* Number of input holes. */
     697             :   int regions;                                   /* Number of input regions. */
     698             :   int undeads;    /* Number of input vertices that don't appear in the mesh. */
     699             :   ptrdiff_t  edges;                                     /* Number of output edges. */
     700             :   int mesh_dim;                                /* Dimension (ought to be 2). */
     701             :   int nextras;                           /* Number of attributes per vertex. */
     702             :   int eextras;                         /* Number of attributes per triangle. */
     703             :   ptrdiff_t  hullsize;                          /* Number of edges in convex hull. */
     704             :   int steinerleft;                 /* Number of Steiner points not yet used. */
     705             :   int vertexmarkindex;         /* Index to find boundary marker of a vertex. */
     706             :   int vertex2triindex;     /* Index to find a triangle adjacent to a vertex. */
     707             :   int highorderindex;  /* Index to find extra nodes for high-order elements. */
     708             :   int elemattribindex;            /* Index to find attributes of a triangle. */
     709             :   int areaboundindex;             /* Index to find area bound of a triangle. */
     710             :   int checksegments;         /* Are there segments in the triangulation yet? */
     711             :   int checkquality;                  /* Has quality triangulation begun yet? */
     712             :   int readnodefile;                           /* Has a .node file been read? */
     713             :   ptrdiff_t  samples;              /* Number of random samples for point location. */
     714             : 
     715             :   ptrdiff_t  incirclecount;                 /* Number of incircle tests performed. */
     716             :   ptrdiff_t  counterclockcount;     /* Number of counterclockwise tests performed. */
     717             :   ptrdiff_t  orient3dcount;           /* Number of 3D orientation tests performed. */
     718             :   ptrdiff_t  hyperbolacount;      /* Number of right-of-hyperbola tests performed. */
     719             :   ptrdiff_t  circumcentercount;  /* Number of circumcenter calculations performed. */
     720             :   ptrdiff_t  circletopcount;       /* Number of circle top calculations performed. */
     721             : 
     722             : /* Triangular bounding box vertices.                                         */
     723             : 
     724             :   vertex infvertex1, infvertex2, infvertex3;
     725             : 
     726             : /* Pointer to the `triangle' that occupies all of "outer space."             */
     727             : 
     728             :   triangle *dummytri;
     729             :   triangle *dummytribase;    /* Keep base address so we can free() it later. */
     730             : 
     731             : /* Pointer to the omnipresent subsegment.  Referenced by any triangle or     */
     732             : /*   subsegment that isn't really connected to a subsegment at that          */
     733             : /*   location.                                                               */
     734             : 
     735             :   subseg *dummysub;
     736             :   subseg *dummysubbase;      /* Keep base address so we can free() it later. */
     737             : 
     738             : /* Pointer to a recently visited triangle.  Improves point location if       */
     739             : /*   proximate vertices are inserted sequentially.                           */
     740             : 
     741             :   struct otri recenttri;
     742             : 
     743             : };                                                  /* End of `struct mesh'. */
     744             : 
     745             : 
     746             : /* Data structure for command line switches and file names.  This structure  */
     747             : /*   is used (instead of global variables) to allow reentrancy.              */
     748             : 
     749             : struct behavior {
     750             : 
     751             : /* Switches for the triangulator.                                            */
     752             : /*   poly: -p switch.  refine: -r switch.                                    */
     753             : /*   quality: -q switch.                                                     */
     754             : /*     minangle: minimum angle bound, specified after -q switch.             */
     755             : /*     goodangle: cosine squared of minangle.                                */
     756             : /*     offconstant: constant used to place off-center Steiner points.        */
     757             : /*   vararea: -a switch without number.                                      */
     758             : /*   fixedarea: -a switch with number.                                       */
     759             : /*     maxarea: maximum area bound, specified after -a switch.               */
     760             : /*   usertest: -u switch.                                                    */
     761             : /*   regionattrib: -A switch.  convex: -c switch.                            */
     762             : /*   weighted: 1 for -w switch, 2 for -W switch.  jettison: -j switch        */
     763             : /*   firstnumber: inverse of -z switch.  All items are numbered starting     */
     764             : /*     from `firstnumber'.                                                   */
     765             : /*   edgesout: -e switch.  voronoi: -v switch.                               */
     766             : /*   neighbors: -n switch.  geomview: -g switch.                             */
     767             : /*   nobound: -B switch.  nopolywritten: -P switch.                          */
     768             : /*   nonodewritten: -N switch.  noelewritten: -E switch.                     */
     769             : /*   noiterationnum: -I switch.  noholes: -O switch.                         */
     770             : /*   noexact: -X switch.                                                     */
     771             : /*   order: element order, specified after -o switch.                        */
     772             : /*   nobisect: count of how often -Y switch is selected.                     */
     773             : /*   steiner: maximum number of Steiner points, specified after -S switch.   */
     774             : /*   incremental: -i switch.  sweepline: -F switch.                          */
     775             : /*   dwyer: inverse of -l switch.                                            */
     776             : /*   splitseg: -s switch.                                                    */
     777             : /*   conformdel: -D switch.  docheck: -C switch.                             */
     778             : /*   quiet: -Q switch.  verbose: count of how often -V switch is selected.   */
     779             : /*   usesegments: -p, -r, -q, or -c switch; determines whether segments are  */
     780             : /*     used at all.                                                          */
     781             : /*                                                                           */
     782             : /* Read the instructions to find out the meaning of these switches.          */
     783             : 
     784             :   int poly, refine, quality, vararea, fixedarea, usertest;
     785             :   int regionattrib, convex, weighted, jettison;
     786             :   int firstnumber;
     787             :   int edgesout, voronoi, neighbors, geomview;
     788             :   int nobound, nopolywritten, nonodewritten, noelewritten, noiterationnum;
     789             :   int noholes, noexact, conformdel;
     790             :   int incremental, sweepline, dwyer;
     791             :   int splitseg;
     792             :   int docheck;
     793             :   int quiet, verbose;
     794             :   int usesegments;
     795             :   int order;
     796             :   int nobisect;
     797             :   int steiner;
     798             :   REAL minangle, goodangle, offconstant;
     799             :   REAL maxarea;
     800             : 
     801             : /* Variables for file names.                                                 */
     802             : 
     803             : #ifndef TRILIBRARY
     804             :   char innodefilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     805             :   char inelefilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     806             :   char inpolyfilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     807             :   char areafilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     808             :   char outnodefilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     809             :   char outelefilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     810             :   char outpolyfilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     811             :   char edgefilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     812             :   char vnodefilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     813             :   char vedgefilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     814             :   char neighborfilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     815             :   char offfilename[FILENAMESIZE];
     816             : #endif /* not TRILIBRARY */
     817             : 
     818             : };                                              /* End of `struct behavior'. */
     819             : 
     820             : 
     821             : /*****************************************************************************/
     822             : /*                                                                           */
     823             : /*  Mesh manipulation primitives.  Each triangle contains three pointers to  */
     824             : /*  other triangles, with orientations.  Each pointer points not to the      */
     825             : /*  first byte of a triangle, but to one of the first three bytes of a       */
     826             : /*  triangle.  It is necessary to extract both the triangle itself and the   */
     827             : /*  orientation.  To save memory, I keep both pieces of information in one   */
     828             : /*  pointer.  To make this possible, I assume that all triangles are aligned */
     829             : /*  to four-byte boundaries.  The decode() routine below decodes a pointer,  */
     830             : /*  extracting an orientation (in the range 0 to 2) and a pointer to the     */
     831             : /*  beginning of a triangle.  The encode() routine compresses a pointer to a */
     832             : /*  triangle and an orientation into a single pointer.  My assumptions that  */
     833             : /*  triangles are four-byte-aligned and that the `size_t' type is     */
     834             : /*  ptrdiff_t  enough to hold a pointer are two of the few kludges in this program.*/
     835             : /*                                                                           */
     836             : /*  Subsegments are manipulated similarly.  A pointer to a subsegment        */
     837             : /*  carries both an address and an orientation in the range 0 to 1.          */
     838             : /*                                                                           */
     839             : /*  The other primitives take an oriented triangle or oriented subsegment,   */
     840             : /*  and return an oriented triangle or oriented subsegment or vertex; or     */
     841             : /*  they change the connections in the data structure.                       */
     842             : /*                                                                           */
     843             : /*  Below, triangles and subsegments are denoted by their vertices.  The     */
     844             : /*  triangle abc has origin (org) a, destination (dest) b, and apex (apex)   */
     845             : /*  c.  These vertices occur in counterclockwise order about the triangle.   */
     846             : /*  The handle abc may simultaneously denote vertex a, edge ab, and triangle */
     847             : /*  abc.                                                                     */
     848             : /*                                                                           */
     849             : /*  Similarly, the subsegment ab has origin (sorg) a and destination (sdest) */
     850             : /*  b.  If ab is thought to be directed upward (with b directly above a),    */
     851             : /*  then the handle ab is thought to grasp the right side of ab, and may     */
     852             : /*  simultaneously denote vertex a and edge ab.                              */
     853             : /*                                                                           */
     854             : /*  An asterisk (*) denotes a vertex whose identity is unknown.              */
     855             : /*                                                                           */
     856             : /*  Given this notation, a partial list of mesh manipulation primitives      */
     857             : /*  follows.                                                                 */
     858             : /*                                                                           */
     859             : /*                                                                           */
     860             : /*  For triangles:                                                           */
     861             : /*                                                                           */
     862             : /*  sym:  Find the abutting triangle; same edge.                             */
     863             : /*  sym(abc) -> ba*                                                          */
     864             : /*                                                                           */
     865             : /*  lnext:  Find the next edge (counterclockwise) of a triangle.             */
     866             : /*  lnext(abc) -> bca                                                        */
     867             : /*                                                                           */
     868             : /*  lprev:  Find the previous edge (clockwise) of a triangle.                */
     869             : /*  lprev(abc) -> cab                                                        */
     870             : /*                                                                           */
     871             : /*  onext:  Find the next edge counterclockwise with the same origin.        */
     872             : /*  onext(abc) -> ac*                                                        */
     873             : /*                                                                           */
     874             : /*  oprev:  Find the next edge clockwise with the same origin.               */
     875             : /*  oprev(abc) -> a*b                                                        */
     876             : /*                                                                           */
     877             : /*  dnext:  Find the next edge counterclockwise with the same destination.   */
     878             : /*  dnext(abc) -> *ba                                                        */
     879             : /*                                                                           */
     880             : /*  dprev:  Find the next edge clockwise with the same destination.          */
     881             : /*  dprev(abc) -> cb*                                                        */
     882             : /*                                                                           */
     883             : /*  rnext:  Find the next edge (counterclockwise) of the adjacent triangle.  */
     884             : /*  rnext(abc) -> *a*                                                        */
     885             : /*                                                                           */
     886             : /*  rprev:  Find the previous edge (clockwise) of the adjacent triangle.     */
     887             : /*  rprev(abc) -> b**                                                        */
     888             : /*                                                                           */
     889             : /*  org:  Origin          dest:  Destination          apex:  Apex            */
     890             : /*  org(abc) -> a         dest(abc) -> b              apex(abc) -> c         */
     891             : /*                                                                           */
     892             : /*  bond:  Bond two triangles together at the resepective handles.           */
     893             : /*  bond(abc, bad)                                                           */
     894             : /*                                                                           */
     895             : /*                                                                           */
     896             : /*  For subsegments:                                                         */
     897             : /*                                                                           */
     898             : /*  ssym:  Reverse the orientation of a subsegment.                          */
     899             : /*  ssym(ab) -> ba                                                           */
     900             : /*                                                                           */
     901             : /*  spivot:  Find adjoining subsegment with the same origin.                 */
     902             : /*  spivot(ab) -> a*                                                         */
     903             : /*                                                                           */
     904             : /*  snext:  Find next subsegment in sequence.                                */
     905             : /*  snext(ab) -> b*                                                          */
     906             : /*                                                                           */
     907             : /*  sorg:  Origin                      sdest:  Destination                   */
     908             : /*  sorg(ab) -> a                      sdest(ab) -> b                        */
     909             : /*                                                                           */
     910             : /*  sbond:  Bond two subsegments together at the respective origins.         */
     911             : /*  sbond(ab, ac)                                                            */
     912             : /*                                                                           */
     913             : /*                                                                           */
     914             : /*  For interacting tetrahedra and subfacets:                                */
     915             : /*                                                                           */
     916             : /*  tspivot:  Find a subsegment abutting a triangle.                         */
     917             : /*  tspivot(abc) -> ba                                                       */
     918             : /*                                                                           */
     919             : /*  stpivot:  Find a triangle abutting a subsegment.                         */
     920             : /*  stpivot(ab) -> ba*                                                       */
     921             : /*                                                                           */
     922             : /*  tsbond:  Bond a triangle to a subsegment.                                */
     923             : /*  tsbond(abc, ba)                                                          */
     924             : /*                                                                           */
     925             : /*****************************************************************************/
     926             : 
     927             : /********* Mesh manipulation primitives begin here                   *********/
     928             : /**                                                                         **/
     929             : /**                                                                         **/
     930             : 
     931             : /* Fast lookup arrays to speed some of the mesh manipulation primitives.     */
     932             : 
     933             : int plus1mod3[3] = {1, 2, 0};
     934             : int minus1mod3[3] = {2, 0, 1};
     935             : 
     936             : /********* Primitives for triangles                                  *********/
     937             : /*                                                                           */
     938             : /*                                                                           */
     939             : 
     940             : /* decode() converts a pointer to an oriented triangle.  The orientation is  */
     941             : /*   extracted from the two least significant bits of the pointer.           */
     942             : 
     943             : #define decode(ptr, otri)                                                     \
     944             :   (otri).orient = (int) ((size_t) (ptr) & (size_t) 3l);         \
     945             :   (otri).tri = (triangle *)                                                   \
     946             :                   ((size_t) (ptr) ^ (size_t) (otri).orient)
     947             : 
     948             : /* encode() compresses an oriented triangle into a single pointer.  It       */
     949             : /*   relies on the assumption that all triangles are aligned to four-byte    */
     950             : /*   boundaries, so the two least significant bits of (otri).tri are zero.   */
     951             : 
     952             : #define encode(otri)                                                          \
     953             :   (triangle) ((size_t) (otri).tri | (size_t) (otri).orient)
     954             :
