     955             : /* The following handle manipulation primitives are all described by Guibas  */
     956             : /*   and Stolfi.  However, Guibas and Stolfi use an edge-based data          */
     957             : /*   structure, whereas I use a triangle-based data structure.               */
     958             : 
     959             : /* sym() finds the abutting triangle, on the same edge.  Note that the edge  */
     960             : /*   direction is necessarily reversed, because the handle specified by an   */
     961             : /*   oriented triangle is directed counterclockwise around the triangle.     */
     962             : 
     963             : #define sym(otri1, otri2)                                                     \
     964             :   ptr = (otri1).tri[(otri1).orient];                                          \
     965             :   decode(ptr, otri2);
     966             : 
     967             : #define symself(otri)                                                         \
     968             :   ptr = (otri).tri[(otri).orient];                                            \
     969             :   decode(ptr, otri);
     970             : 
     971             : /* lnext() finds the next edge (counterclockwise) of a triangle.             */
     972             : 
     973             : #define lnext(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
     974             :   (otri2).tri = (otri1).tri;                                                  \
     975             :   (otri2).orient = plus1mod3[(otri1).orient]
     976             : 
     977             : #define lnextself(otri)                                                       \
     978             :   (otri).orient = plus1mod3[(otri).orient]
     979             : 
     980             : /* lprev() finds the previous edge (clockwise) of a triangle.                */
     981             : 
     982             : #define lprev(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
     983             :   (otri2).tri = (otri1).tri;                                                  \
     984             :   (otri2).orient = minus1mod3[(otri1).orient]
     985             : 
     986             : #define lprevself(otri)                                                       \
     987             :   (otri).orient = minus1mod3[(otri).orient]
     988             : 
     989             : /* onext() spins counterclockwise around a vertex; that is, it finds the     */
     990             : /*   next edge with the same origin in the counterclockwise direction.  This */
     991             : /*   edge is part of a different triangle.                                   */
     992             : 
     993             : #define onext(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
     994             :   lprev(otri1, otri2);                                                        \
     995             :   symself(otri2);
     996             : 
     997             : #define onextself(otri)                                                       \
     998             :   lprevself(otri);                                                            \
     999             :   symself(otri);
    1000             : 
    1001             : /* oprev() spins clockwise around a vertex; that is, it finds the next edge  */
    1002             : /*   with the same origin in the clockwise direction.  This edge is part of  */
    1003             : /*   a different triangle.                                                   */
    1004             : 
    1005             : #define oprev(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
    1006             :   sym(otri1, otri2);                                                          \
    1007             :   lnextself(otri2);
    1008             : 
    1009             : #define oprevself(otri)                                                       \
    1010             :   symself(otri);                                                              \
    1011             :   lnextself(otri);
    1012             : 
    1013             : /* dnext() spins counterclockwise around a vertex; that is, it finds the     */
    1014             : /*   next edge with the same destination in the counterclockwise direction.  */
    1015             : /*   This edge is part of a different triangle.                              */
    1016             : 
    1017             : #define dnext(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
    1018             :   sym(otri1, otri2);                                                          \
    1019             :   lprevself(otri2);
    1020             : 
    1021             : #define dnextself(otri)                                                       \
    1022             :   symself(otri);                                                              \
    1023             :   lprevself(otri);
    1024             : 
    1025             : /* dprev() spins clockwise around a vertex; that is, it finds the next edge  */
    1026             : /*   with the same destination in the clockwise direction.  This edge is     */
    1027             : /*   part of a different triangle.                                           */
    1028             : 
    1029             : #define dprev(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
    1030             :   lnext(otri1, otri2);                                                        \
    1031             :   symself(otri2);
    1032             : 
    1033             : #define dprevself(otri)                                                       \
    1034             :   lnextself(otri);                                                            \
    1035             :   symself(otri);
    1036             : 
    1037             : /* rnext() moves one edge counterclockwise about the adjacent triangle.      */
    1038             : /*   (It's best understood by reading Guibas and Stolfi.  It involves        */
    1039             : /*   changing triangles twice.)                                              */
    1040             : 
    1041             : #define rnext(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
    1042             :   sym(otri1, otri2);                                                          \
    1043             :   lnextself(otri2);                                                           \
    1044             :   symself(otri2);
    1045             : 
    1046             : #define rnextself(otri)                                                       \
    1047             :   symself(otri);                                                              \
    1048             :   lnextself(otri);                                                            \
    1049             :   symself(otri);
    1050             : 
    1051             : /* rprev() moves one edge clockwise about the adjacent triangle.             */
    1052             : /*   (It's best understood by reading Guibas and Stolfi.  It involves        */
    1053             : /*   changing triangles twice.)                                              */
    1054             : 
    1055             : #define rprev(otri1, otri2)                                                   \
    1056             :   sym(otri1, otri2);                                                          \
    1057             :   lprevself(otri2);                                                           \
    1058             :   symself(otri2);
    1059             : 
    1060             : #define rprevself(otri)                                                       \
    1061             :   symself(otri);                                                              \
    1062             :   lprevself(otri);                                                            \
    1063             :   symself(otri);
    1064             : 
    1065             : /* These primitives determine or set the origin, destination, or apex of a   */
    1066             : /* triangle.                                                                 */
    1067             : 
    1068             : #define org(otri, vertexptr)                                                  \
    1069             :   vertexptr = (vertex) (otri).tri[plus1mod3[(otri).orient] + 3]
    1070             : 
    1071             : #define dest(otri, vertexptr)                                                 \
    1072             :   vertexptr = (vertex) (otri).tri[minus1mod3[(otri).orient] + 3]
    1073             : 
    1074             : #define apex(otri, vertexptr)                                                 \
    1075             :   vertexptr = (vertex) (otri).tri[(otri).orient + 3]
    1076             : 
    1077             : #define setorg(otri, vertexptr)                                               \
    1078             :   (otri).tri[plus1mod3[(otri).orient] + 3] = (triangle) vertexptr
    1079             : 
    1080             : #define setdest(otri, vertexptr)                                              \
    1081             :   (otri).tri[minus1mod3[(otri).orient] + 3] = (triangle) vertexptr
    1082             : 
    1083             : #define setapex(otri, vertexptr)                                              \
    1084             :   (otri).tri[(otri).orient + 3] = (triangle) vertexptr
    1085             : 
    1086             : /* Bond two triangles together.                                              */
    1087             : 
    1088             : #define bond(otri1, otri2)                                                    \
    1089             :   (otri1).tri[(otri1).orient] = encode(otri2);                                \
    1090             :   (otri2).tri[(otri2).orient] = encode(otri1)
    1091             : 
    1092             : /* Dissolve a bond (from one side).  Note that the other triangle will still */
    1093             : /*   think it's connected to this triangle.  Usually, however, the other     */
    1094             : /*   triangle is being deleted entirely, or bonded to another triangle, so   */
    1095             : /*   it doesn't matter.                                                      */
    1096             : 
    1097             : #define dissolve(otri)                                                        \
    1098             :   (otri).tri[(otri).orient] = (triangle) m->dummytri
    1099             : 
    1100             : /* Copy an oriented triangle.                                                */
    1101             : 
    1102             : #define otricopy(otri1, otri2)                                                \
    1103             :   (otri2).tri = (otri1).tri;                                                  \
    1104             :   (otri2).orient = (otri1).orient
    1105             : 
    1106             : /* Test for equality of oriented triangles.                                  */
    1107             : 
    1108             : #define otriequal(otri1, otri2)                                               \
    1109             :   (((otri1).tri == (otri2).tri) &&                                            \
    1110             :    ((otri1).orient == (otri2).orient))
    1111             : 
    1112             : /* Primitives to infect or cure a triangle with the virus.  These rely on    */
    1113             : /*   the assumption that all subsegments are aligned to four-byte boundaries.*/
    1114             : 
    1115             : #define infect(otri)                                                          \
    1116             :   (otri).tri[6] = (triangle)                                                  \
    1117             :                     ((size_t) (otri).tri[6] | (size_t) 2l)
    1118             : 
    1119             : #define uninfect(otri)                                                        \
    1120             :   (otri).tri[6] = (triangle)                                                  \
    1121             :                     ((size_t) (otri).tri[6] & ~ (size_t) 2l)
    1122             : 
    1123             : /* Test a triangle for viral infection.                                      */
    1124             : 
    1125             : #define infected(otri)                                                        \
    1126             :   (((size_t) (otri).tri[6] & (size_t) 2l) != 0l)
    1127             : 
    1128             : /* Check or set a triangle's attributes.                                     */
    1129             : 
    1130             : #define elemattribute(otri, attnum)                                           \
    1131             :   ((REAL *) (otri).tri)[m->elemattribindex + (attnum)]
    1132             : 
    1133             : #define setelemattribute(otri, attnum, value)                                 \
    1134             :   ((REAL *) (otri).tri)[m->elemattribindex + (attnum)] = value
    1135             : 
    1136             : /* Check or set a triangle's maximum area bound.                             */
    1137             : 
    1138             : #define areabound(otri)  ((REAL *) (otri).tri)[m->areaboundindex]
    1139             : 
    1140             : #define setareabound(otri, value)                                             \
    1141             :   ((REAL *) (otri).tri)[m->areaboundindex] = value
    1142             : 
    1143             : /* Check or set a triangle's deallocation.  Its second pointer is set to     */
    1144             : /*   NULL to indicate that it is not allocated.  (Its first pointer is used  */
    1145             : /*   for the stack of dead items.)  Its fourth pointer (its first vertex)    */
    1146             : /*   is set to NULL in case a `badtriang' structure points to it.            */
    1147             : 
    1148             : #define deadtri(tria)  ((tria)[1] == (triangle) NULL)
    1149             : 
    1150             : #define killtri(tria)                                                         \
    1151             :   (tria)[1] = (triangle) NULL;                                                \
    1152             :   (tria)[3] = (triangle) NULL
    1153             : 
    1154             : /********* Primitives for subsegments                                *********/
    1155             : /*                                                                           */
    1156             : /*                                                                           */
    1157             : 
    1158             : /* sdecode() converts a pointer to an oriented subsegment.  The orientation  */
    1159             : /*   is extracted from the least significant bit of the pointer.  The two    */
    1160             : /*   least significant bits (one for orientation, one for viral infection)   */
    1161             : /*   are masked out to produce the real pointer.                             */
    1162             : 
    1163             : #define sdecode(sptr, osub)                                                   \
    1164             :   (osub).ssorient = (int) ((size_t) (sptr) & (size_t) 1l);      \
    1165             :   (osub).ss = (subseg *)                                                      \
    1166             :               ((size_t) (sptr) & ~ (size_t) 3l)
    1167             : 
    1168             : /* sencode() compresses an oriented subsegment into a single pointer.  It    */
    1169             : /*   relies on the assumption that all subsegments are aligned to two-byte   */
    1170             : /*   boundaries, so the least significant bit of (osub).ss is zero.          */
    1171             : 
    1172             : #define sencode(osub)                                                         \
    1173             :   (subseg) ((size_t) (osub).ss | (size_t) (osub).ssorient)
    1174             : 
    1175             : /* ssym() toggles the orientation of a subsegment.                           */
    1176             : 
    1177             : #define ssym(osub1, osub2)                                                    \
    1178             :   (osub2).ss = (osub1).ss;                                                    \
    1179             :   (osub2).ssorient = 1 - (osub1).ssorient
    1180             : 
    1181             : #define ssymself(osub)                                                        \
    1182             :   (osub).ssorient = 1 - (osub).ssorient
    1183             : 
    1184             : /* spivot() finds the other subsegment (from the same segment) that shares   */
    1185             : /*   the same origin.                                                        */
    1186             : 
    1187             : #define spivot(osub1, osub2)                                                  \
    1188             :   sptr = (osub1).ss[(osub1).ssorient];                                        \
    1189             :   sdecode(sptr, osub2)
    1190             : 
    1191             : #define spivotself(osub)                                                      \
    1192             :   sptr = (osub).ss[(osub).ssorient];                                          \
    1193             :   sdecode(sptr, osub)
    1194             : 
    1195             : /* snext() finds the next subsegment (from the same segment) in sequence;    */
    1196             : /*   one whose origin is the input subsegment's destination.                 */
    1197             : 
    1198             : #define snext(osub1, osub2)                                                   \
    1199             :   sptr = (osub1).ss[1 - (osub1).ssorient];                                    \
    1200             :   sdecode(sptr, osub2)
    1201             : 
    1202             : #define snextself(osub)                                                       \
    1203             :   sptr = (osub).ss[1 - (osub).ssorient];                                      \
    1204             :   sdecode(sptr, osub)
    1205             : 
    1206             : /* These primitives determine or set the origin or destination of a          */
    1207             : /*   subsegment or the segment that includes it.                             */
    1208             : 
    1209             : #define sorg(osub, vertexptr)                                                 \
    1210             :   vertexptr = (vertex) (osub).ss[2 + (osub).ssorient]
    1211             : 
    1212             : #define sdest(osub, vertexptr)                                                \
    1213             :   vertexptr = (vertex) (osub).ss[3 - (osub).ssorient]
    1214             : 
    1215             : #define setsorg(osub, vertexptr)                                              \
    1216             :   (osub).ss[2 + (osub).ssorient] = (subseg) vertexptr
    1217             : 
    1218             : #define setsdest(osub, vertexptr)                                             \
    1219             :   (osub).ss[3 - (osub).ssorient] = (subseg) vertexptr
    1220             : 
    1221             : #define segorg(osub, vertexptr)                                               \
    1222             :   vertexptr = (vertex) (osub).ss[4 + (osub).ssorient]
    1223             : 
    1224             : #define segdest(osub, vertexptr)                                              \
    1225             :   vertexptr = (vertex) (osub).ss[5 - (osub).ssorient]
    1226             : 
    1227             : #define setsegorg(osub, vertexptr)                                            \
    1228             :   (osub).ss[4 + (osub).ssorient] = (subseg) vertexptr
    1229             : 
    1230             : #define setsegdest(osub, vertexptr)                                           \
    1231             :   (osub).ss[5 - (osub).ssorient] = (subseg) vertexptr
    1232             : 
    1233             : /* These primitives read or set a boundary marker.  Boundary markers are     */
    1234             : /*   used to hold user-defined tags for setting boundary conditions in       */
    1235             : /*   finite element solvers.                                                 */
    1236             : 
    1237             : #define mark(osub)  (* (int *) ((osub).ss + 8))
    1238             : 
    1239             : #define setmark(osub, value)                                                  \
    1240             :   * (int *) ((osub).ss + 8) = value
    1241             : 
    1242             : /* Bond two subsegments together.                                            */
    1243             : 
    1244             : #define sbond(osub1, osub2)                                                   \
    1245             :   (osub1).ss[(osub1).ssorient] = sencode(osub2);                              \
    1246             :   (osub2).ss[(osub2).ssorient] = sencode(osub1)
    1247             : 
    1248             : /* Dissolve a subsegment bond (from one side).  Note that the other          */
    1249             : /*   subsegment will still think it's connected to this subsegment.          */
    1250             : 
    1251             : #define sdissolve(osub)                                                       \
    1252             :   (osub).ss[(osub).ssorient] = (subseg) m->dummysub
    1253             : 
    1254             : /* Copy a subsegment.                                                        */
    1255             : 
    1256             : #define subsegcopy(osub1, osub2)                                              \
    1257             :   (osub2).ss = (osub1).ss;                                                    \
    1258             :   (osub2).ssorient = (osub1).ssorient
    1259             : 
    1260             : /* Test for equality of subsegments.                                         */
    1261             : 
    1262             : #define subsegequal(osub1, osub2)                                             \
    1263             :   (((osub1).ss == (osub2).ss) &&                                              \
    1264             :    ((osub1).ssorient == (osub2).ssorient))
    1265             : 
    1266             : /* Check or set a subsegment's deallocation.  Its second pointer is set to   */
    1267             : /*   NULL to indicate that it is not allocated.  (Its first pointer is used  */
    1268             : /*   for the stack of dead items.)  Its third pointer (its first vertex)     */
    1269             : /*   is set to NULL in case a `badsubseg' structure points to it.            */
    1270             : 
    1271             : #define deadsubseg(sub)  ((sub)[1] == (subseg) NULL)
    1272             : 
    1273             : #define killsubseg(sub)                                                       \
    1274             :   (sub)[1] = (subseg) NULL;                                                   \
    1275             :   (sub)[2] = (subseg) NULL
    1276             : 
    1277             : /********* Primitives for interacting triangles and subsegments      *********/
    1278             : /*                                                                           */
    1279             : /*                                                                           */
    1280             : 
    1281             : /* tspivot() finds a subsegment abutting a triangle.                         */
    1282             : 
    1283             : #define tspivot(otri, osub)                                                   \
    1284             :   sptr = (subseg) (otri).tri[6 + (otri).orient];                              \
    1285             :   sdecode(sptr, osub)
    1286             : 
    1287             : /* stpivot() finds a triangle abutting a subsegment.  It requires that the   */
    1288             : /*   variable `ptr' of type `triangle' be defined.                           */
    1289             : 
    1290             : #define stpivot(osub, otri)                                                   \
    1291             :   ptr = (triangle) (osub).ss[6 + (osub).ssorient];                            \
    1292             :   decode(ptr, otri)
    1293             : 
    1294             : /* Bond a triangle to a subsegment.                                          */
    1295             : 
    1296             : #define tsbond(otri, osub)                                                    \
    1297             :   (otri).tri[6 + (otri).orient] = (triangle) sencode(osub);                   \
    1298             :   (osub).ss[6 + (osub).ssorient] = (subseg) encode(otri)
    1299             : 
    1300             : /* Dissolve a bond (from the triangle side).                                 */
    1301             : 
    1302             : #define tsdissolve(otri)                                                      \
    1303             :   (otri).tri[6 + (otri).orient] = (triangle) m->dummysub
    1304             : 
    1305             : /* Dissolve a bond (from the subsegment side).                               */
    1306             : 
    1307             : #define stdissolve(osub)                                                      \
    1308             :   (osub).ss[6 + (osub).ssorient] = (subseg) m->dummytri
    1309             : 
    1310             : /********* Primitives for vertices                                   *********/
    1311             : /*                                                                           */
    1312             : /*                                                                           */
    1313             : 
    1314             : #define vertexmark(vx)  ((int *) (vx))[m->vertexmarkindex]
    1315             : 
    1316             : #define setvertexmark(vx, value)                                              \
    1317             :   ((int *) (vx))[m->vertexmarkindex] = value
    1318             : 
    1319             : #define vertextype(vx)  ((int *) (vx))[m->vertexmarkindex + 1]
    1320             : 
    1321             : #define setvertextype(vx, value)                                              \
    1322             :   ((int *) (vx))[m->vertexmarkindex + 1] = value
    1323             : 
    1324             : #define vertex2tri(vx)  ((triangle *) (vx))[m->vertex2triindex]
    1325             : 
    1326             : #define setvertex2tri(vx, value)                                              \
    1327             :   ((triangle *) (vx))[m->vertex2triindex] = value
    1328             : 
    1329             : /**                                                                         **/
    1330             : /**                                                                         **/
    1331             : /********* Mesh manipulation primitives end here                     *********/
    1332             : 
    1333             : /********* User-defined triangle evaluation routine begins here      *********/
    1334             : /**                                                                         **/
    1335             : /**                                                                         **/
    1336             : 
    1337             : /*****************************************************************************/
    1338             : /*                                                                           */
    1339             : /*  triunsuitable()   Determine if a triangle is unsuitable, and thus must   */
    1340             : /*                    be further refined.                                    */
    1341             : /*                                                                           */
    1342             : /*  You may write your own procedure that decides whether or not a selected  */
    1343             : /*  triangle is too big (and needs to be refined).  There are two ways to do */
    1344             : /*  this.                                                                    */
    1345             : /*                                                                           */
    1346             : /*  (1)  Modify the procedure `triunsuitable' below, then recompile          */
    1347             : /*  Triangle.                                                                */
    1348             : /*                                                                           */
    1349             : /*  (2)  Define the symbol EXTERNAL_TEST (either by adding the definition    */
    1350             : /*  to this file, or by using the appropriate compiler switch).  This way,   */
    1351             : /*  you can compile triangle.c separately from your test.  Write your own    */
    1352             : /*  `triunsuitable' procedure in a separate C file (using the same prototype */
    1353             : /*  as below).  Compile it and link the object code with triangle.o.         */
    1354             : /*                                                                           */
    1355             : /*  This procedure returns 1 if the triangle is too large and should be      */
    1356             : /*  refined; 0 otherwise.                                                    */
    1357             : /*                                                                           */
    1358             : /*****************************************************************************/
    1359             : 
    1360             : #ifdef EXTERNAL_TEST
    1361             : 
    1362             : int triunsuitable();
    1363             : 
    1364             : #else /* not EXTERNAL_TEST */
    1365             : 
    1366             : #ifdef ANSI_DECLARATORS
    1367             : int triunsuitable(vertex triorg, vertex tridest, vertex triapex, REAL area)
    1368             : #else /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1369           0 : int triunsuitable(triorg, tridest, triapex, area)
    1370             : vertex triorg;                              /* The triangle's origin vertex. */
    1371             : vertex tridest;                        /* The triangle's destination vertex. */
    1372             : vertex triapex;                               /* The triangle's apex vertex. */
    1373             : REAL area;                                      /* The area of the triangle. */
    1374             : #endif /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1375             : 
    1376             : {
    1377             :   REAL dxoa, dxda, dxod;
    1378             :   REAL dyoa, dyda, dyod;
    1379             :   REAL oalen, dalen, odlen;
    1380             :   REAL maxlen;
    1381             : 
    1382           0 :   dxoa = triorg[0] - triapex[0];
    1383           0 :   dyoa = triorg[1] - triapex[1];
    1384           0 :   dxda = tridest[0] - triapex[0];
    1385           0 :   dyda = tridest[1] - triapex[1];
    1386           0 :   dxod = triorg[0] - tridest[0];
    1387           0 :   dyod = triorg[1] - tridest[1];
    1388             :   /* Find the squares of the lengths of the triangle's three edges. */
    1389           0 :   oalen = dxoa * dxoa + dyoa * dyoa;
    1390           0 :   dalen = dxda * dxda + dyda * dyda;
    1391           0 :   odlen = dxod * dxod + dyod * dyod;
    1392             :   /* Find the square of the length of the longest edge. */
    1393           0 :   maxlen = (dalen > oalen) ? dalen : oalen;
    1394           0 :   maxlen = (odlen > maxlen) ? odlen : maxlen;
    1395             : 
    1396           0 :   if (maxlen > 0.05 * (triorg[0] * triorg[0] + triorg[1] * triorg[1]) + 0.02) {
    1397           0 :     return 1;
    1398             :   } else {
    1399           0 :     return 0;
    1400             :   }
    1401             : }
    1402             : 
    1403             : #endif /* not EXTERNAL_TEST */
    1404             : 
    1405             : /**                                                                         **/
    1406             : /**                                                                         **/
    1407             : /********* User-defined triangle evaluation routine ends here        *********/
    1408             : 
    1409             : /********* Memory allocation and program exit wrappers begin here    *********/
    1410             : /**                                                                         **/
    1411             : /**                                                                         **/
    1412             : 
    1413             : #ifdef ANSI_DECLARATORS
    1414             : void triexit(int status)
    1415             : #else /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1416           0 : void triexit(status)
    1417             : int status;
    1418             : #endif /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1419             : 
    1420             : {
    1421           0 :   exit(status);
    1422             : }
    1423             : 
    1424             : #ifdef ANSI_DECLARATORS
    1425             : VOID *trimalloc(int size)
    1426             : #else /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1427           0 : VOID *trimalloc(size)
    1428             : int size;
    1429             : #endif /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1430             : 
    1431             : {
    1432             :   VOID *memptr;
    1433             : 
    1434           0 :   memptr = (VOID *) malloc((unsigned int) size);
    1435           0 :   if (memptr == (VOID *) NULL) {
    1436           0 :     printf("Error:  Out of memory.\n");
    1437           0 :     triexit(1);
    1438             :   }
    1439           0 :   return(memptr);
    1440             : }
    1441             : 
    1442             : #ifdef ANSI_DECLARATORS
    1443             : void trifree(VOID *memptr)
    1444             : #else /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1445           0 : void trifree(memptr)
    1446             : VOID *memptr;
    1447             : #endif /* not ANSI_DECLARATORS */
    1448             : 
    1449             : {
    1450           0 :   free(memptr);
    1451           0 : }
    1452             : 
    1453             : /**                                                                         **/
    1454             : /**                                                                         **/
    1455             : /********* Memory allocation and program exit wrappers end here      *********/
    1456             : 
    1457             : /********* User interaction routines begin here                      *********/
    1458             : /**                                                                         **/
    1459             : /**                                                                         **/
    1460             : 
    1461             : /*****************************************************************************/
    1462             : /*                                                                           */
    1463             : /*  syntax()   Print list of command line switches.                          */
    1464             : /*                                                                           */
    1465             : /*****************************************************************************/
    1466             : 
    1467             : #ifndef TRILIBRARY
    1468             : 
    1469             : void syntax()
    1470             : {
    1471             : #ifdef CDT_ONLY
    1472             : #ifdef REDUCED
    1473             :   printf("triangle [-pAcjevngBPNEIOXzo_lQVh] input_file\n");
    1474             : #else /* not REDUCED */
    1475             :   printf("triangle [-pAcjevngBPNEIOXzo_iFlCQVh] input_file\n");
    1476             : #endif /* not REDUCED */
    1477             : #else /* not CDT_ONLY */
    1478             : #ifdef REDUCED
    1479             :   printf("triangle [-prq__a__uAcDjevngBPNEIOXzo_YS__lQVh] input_file\n");
    1480             : #else /* not REDUCED */
    1481             :   printf("triangle [-prq__a__uAcDjevngBPNEIOXzo_YS__iFlsCQVh] input_file\n");
    1482             : #endif /* not REDUCED */
    1483             : #endif /* not CDT_ONLY */
    1484             : 
    1485             :   printf("    -p  Triangulates a Planar Straight Line Graph (.poly file).\n");
    1486             : #ifndef CDT_ONLY
    1487             :   printf("    -r  Refines a previously generated mesh.\n");
    1488             :   printf(
    1489             :     "    -q  Quality mesh generation.  A minimum angle may be specified.\n");
    1490             :   printf("    -a  Applies a maximum triangle area constraint.\n");
    1491             :   printf("    -u  Applies a user-defined triangle constraint.\n");
    1492             : #endif /* not CDT_ONLY */
    1493             :   printf(
    1494             :     "    -A  Applies attributes to identify triangles in certain regions.\n");
    1495             :   printf("    -c  Encloses the convex hull with segments.\n");
    1496             : #ifndef CDT_ONLY
    1497             :   printf("    -D  Conforming Delaunay:  all triangles are truly Delaunay.\n");
    1498             : #endif /* not CDT_ONLY */
    1499             : /*
    1500             :   printf("    -w  Weighted Delaunay triangulation.\n");
    1501             :   printf("    -W  Regular triangulation (lower hull of a height field).\n");
    1502             : */
    1503             :   printf("    -j  Jettison unused vertices from output .node file.\n");
    1504             :   printf("    -e  Generates an edge list.\n");
    1505             :   printf("    -v  Generates a Voronoi diagram.\n");
    1506             :   printf("    -n  Generates a list of triangle neighbors.\n");
    1507             :   printf("    -g  Generates an .off file for Geomview.\n");
    1508             :   printf("    -B  Suppresses output of boundary information.\n");
    1509             :   printf("    -P  Suppresses output of .poly file.\n");
    1510             :   printf("    -N  Suppresses output of .node file.\n");
    1511             :   printf("    -E  Suppresses output of .ele file.\n");
    1512             :   printf("    -I  Suppresses mesh iteration numbers.\n");
    1513             :   printf("    -O  Ignores holes in .poly file.\n");
    1514             :   printf("    -X  Suppresses use of exact arithmetic.\n");
    1515             :   printf("    -z  Numbers all items starting from zero (rather than one).\n");
    1516             :   printf("    -o2 Generates second-order subparametric elements.\n");
    1517             : #ifndef CDT_ONLY
    1518             :   printf("    -Y  Suppresses boundary segment splitting.\n");
    1519             :   printf("    -S  Specifies maximum number of added Steiner points.\n");
    1520             : #endif /* not CDT_ONLY */
    1521             : #ifndef REDUCED
    1522             :   printf("    -i  Uses incremental method, rather than divide-and-conquer.\n");
    1523             :   printf("    -F  Uses Fortune's sweepline algorithm, rather than d-and-c.\n");
    1524             : #endif /* not REDUCED */
    1525             :   printf("    -l  Uses vertical cuts only, rather than alternating cuts.\n");
    1526             : #ifndef REDUCED
    1527             : #ifndef CDT_ONLY
    1528             :   printf(
    1529             :     "    -s  Force segments into mesh by splitting (instead of using CDT).\n");
    1530             : #endif /* not CDT_ONLY */
    1531             :   printf("    -C  Check consistency of final mesh.\n");
    1532             : #endif /* not REDUCED */
    1533             :   printf("    -Q  Quiet:  No terminal output except errors.\n");
    1534             :   printf("    -V  Verbose:  Detailed information on what I'm doing.\n");
    1535             :   printf("    -h  Help:  Detailed instructions for Triangle.\n");
    1536             :   triexit(0);
    1537             : }
    1538             : 
    1539             : #endif /* not TRILIBRARY */
    1540             : 
    1541             : /*****************************************************************************/
    1542             : /*                                                                           */
    1543             : /*  info()   Print out complete instructions.                                */
    1544             : /*                                                                           */
    1545             : /*****************************************************************************/
    1546             : 
    1547             : #ifndef TRILIBRARY
    1548             : 
    1549             : void info()
    1550             : {
    1551             :   printf("Triangle\n");
    1552             :   printf(
    1553             : "A Two-Dimensional Quality Mesh Generator and Delaunay Triangulator.\n");
    1554             :   printf("Version 1.6\n\n");
    1555             :   printf(
    1556             : "Copyright 1993, 1995, 1997, 1998, 2002, 2005 Jonathan Richard Shewchuk\n");
    1557             :   printf("2360 Woolsey #H / Berkeley, California 94705-1927\n");
    1558             :   printf("Bugs/comments to jrs@cs.berkeley.edu\n");
    1559             :   printf(
    1560             : "Created as part of the Quake project (tools for earthquake simulation).\n");
    1561             :   printf(
    1562             : "Supported in part by NSF Grant CMS-9318163 and an NSERC 1967 Scholarship.\n");
    1563             :   printf("There is no warranty whatsoever.  Use at your own risk.\n");
    1564             : #ifdef SINGLE
    1565             :   printf("This executable is compiled for single precision arithmetic.\n\n\n");
    1566             : #else /* not SINGLE */
    1567             :   printf("This executable is compiled for double precision arithmetic.\n\n\n");
    1568             : #endif /* not SINGLE */
    1569             :   printf(
    1570             : "Triangle generates exact Delaunay triangulations, constrained Delaunay\n");
    1571             :   printf(
    1572             : "triangulations, conforming Delaunay triangulations, Voronoi diagrams, and\n");
    1573             :   printf(
    1574             : "high-quality triangular meshes.  The latter can be generated with no small\n"
    1575             : );
    1576             :   printf(
    1577             : "or large angles, and are thus suitable for finite element analysis.  If no\n"
    1578             : );
    1579             :   printf(
    1580             : "command line switch is specified, your .node input file is read, and the\n");
    1581             :   printf(
    1582             : "Delaunay triangulation is returned in .node and .ele output files.  The\n");
    1583             :   printf("command syntax is:\n\n");
    1584             :   printf("triangle [-prq__a__uAcDjevngBPNEIOXzo_YS__iFlsCQVh] input_file\n\n");
    1585             :   printf(
    1586             : "Underscores indicate that numbers may optionally follow certain switches.\n");
    1587             :   printf(
    1588             : "Do not leave any space between a switch and its numeric parameter.\n");
    1589             :   printf(
    1590             : "input_file must be a file with extension .node, or extension .poly if the\n");
    1591             :   printf(
    1592             : "-p switch is used.  If -r is used, you must supply .node and .ele files,\n");
    1593             :   printf(
    1594             : "and possibly a .poly file and an .area file as well.  The formats of these\n"
    1595             : );
    1596             :   printf("files are described below.\n\n");
    1597             :   printf("Command Line Switches:\n\n");
    1598             :   printf(
    1599             : "    -p  Reads a Planar Straight Line Graph (.poly file), which can specify\n"
    1600             : );
    1601             :   printf(
    1602             : "        vertices, segments, holes, regional attributes, and regional area\n");
    1603             :   printf(
    1604             : "        constraints.  Generates a constrained Delaunay triangulation (CDT)\n"
    1605             : );
    1606             :   printf(
    1607             : "        fitting the input; or, if -s, -q, -a, or -u is used, a conforming\n");
    1608             :   printf(
    1609             : "        constrained Delaunay triangulation (CCDT).  If you want a truly\n");
    1610             :   printf(
    1611             : "        Delaunay (not just constrained Delaunay) triangulation, use -D as\n");
    1612             :   printf(
    1613             : "        well.  When -p is not used, Triangle reads a .node file by default.\n"
    1614             : );
    1615             :   printf(
    1616             : "    -r  Refines a previously generated mesh.  The mesh is read from a .node\n"
    1617             : );
    1618             :   printf(
    1619             : "        file and an .ele file.  If -p is also used, a .poly file is read\n");
    1620             :   printf(
    1621             : "        and used to constrain segments in the mesh.  If -a is also used\n");
    1622             :   printf(
    1623             : "        (with no number following), an .area file is read and used to\n");
    1624             :   printf(
    1625             : "        impose area constraints on the mesh.  Further details on refinement\n"
    1626             : );
    1627             :   printf("        appear below.\n");
    1628             :   printf(
    1629             : "    -q  Quality mesh generation by Delaunay refinement (a hybrid of Paul\n");
    1630             :   printf(
    1631             : "        Chew's and Jim Ruppert's algorithms).  Adds vertices to the mesh to\n"
    1632             : );
    1633             :   printf(
    1634             : "        ensure that all angles are between 20 and 140 degrees.  An\n");
    1635             :   printf(
    1636             : "        alternative bound on the minimum angle, replacing 20 degrees, may\n");
    1637             :   printf(
    1638             : "        be specified after the `q'.  The specified angle may include a\n");
    1639             :   printf(
    1640             : "        decimal point, but not exponential notation.  Note that a bound of\n"
    1641             : );
    1642             :   printf(
    1643             : "        theta degrees on the smallest angle also implies a bound of\n");
    1644             :   printf(
    1645             : "        (180 - 2 theta) on the largest angle.  If the minimum angle is 28.6\n"
    1646             : );
    1647             :   printf(
    1648             : "        degrees or smaller, Triangle is mathematically guaranteed to\n");
    1649             :   printf(
    1650             : "        terminate (assuming infinite precision arithmetic--Triangle may\n");
    1651             :   printf(
    1652             : "        fail to terminate if you run out of precision).  In practice,\n");
    1653             :   printf(
    1654             : "        Triangle often succeeds for minimum angles up to 34 degrees.  For\n");
    1655             :   printf(
    1656             : "        some meshes, however, you might need to reduce the minimum angle to\n"
    1657             : );
    1658             :   printf(
    1659             : "        avoid problems associated with insufficient floating-point\n");
    1660             :   printf("        precision.\n");
    1661             :   printf(
    1662             : "    -a  Imposes a maximum triangle area.  If a number follows the `a', no\n");
    1663             :   printf(
    1664             : "        triangle is generated whose area is larger than that number.  If no\n"
    1665             : );
    1666             :   printf(
    1667             : "        number is specified, an .area file (if -r is used) or .poly file\n");
    1668             :   printf(
    1669             : "        (if -r is not used) specifies a set of maximum area constraints.\n");
    1670             :   printf(
    1671             : "        An .area file contains a separate area constraint for each\n");
    1672             :   printf(
    1673             : "        triangle, and is useful for refining a finite element mesh based on\n"
    1674             : );
    1675             :   printf(
    1676             : "        a posteriori error estimates.  A .poly file can optionally contain\n"
    1677             : );
    1678             :   printf(
    1679             : "        an area constraint for each segment-bounded region, thereby\n");
    1680             :   printf(
    1681             : "        controlling triangle densities in a first triangulation of a PSLG.\n"
    1682             : );
    1683             :   printf(
    1684             : "        You can impose both a fixed area constraint and a varying area\n");
    1685             :   printf(
    1686             : "        constraint by invoking the -a switch twice, once with and once\n");
    1687             :   printf(
    1688             : "        without a number following.  Each area specified may include a\n");
    1689             :   printf("        decimal point.\n");
    1690             :   printf(
    1691             : "    -u  Imposes a user-defined constraint on triangle size.  There are two\n"
    1692             : );
    1693             :   printf(
    1694             : "        ways to use this feature.  One is to edit the triunsuitable()\n");
    1695             :   printf(
    1696             : "        procedure in triangle.c to encode any constraint you like, then\n");
    1697             :   printf(
    1698             : "        recompile Triangle.  The other is to compile triangle.c with the\n");
    1699             :   printf(
    1700             : "        EXTERNAL_TEST symbol set (compiler switch -DEXTERNAL_TEST), then\n");
    1701             :   printf(
    1702             : "        link Triangle with a separate object file that implements\n");
    1703             :   printf(
    1704             : "        triunsuitable().  In either case, the -u switch causes the user-\n");
    1705             :   printf("        defined test to be applied to every triangle.\n");
    1706             :   printf(
    1707             : "    -A  Assigns an additional floating-point attribute to each triangle\n");
    1708             :   printf(
    1709             : "        that identifies what segment-bounded region each triangle belongs\n");
    1710             :   printf(
    1711             : "        to.  Attributes are assigned to regions by the .poly file.  If a\n");
    1712             :   printf(
    1713             : "        region is not explicitly marked by the .poly file, triangles in\n");
    1714             :   printf(
    1715             : "        that region are assigned an attribute of zero.  The -A switch has\n");
    1716             :   printf(
    1717             : "        an effect only when the -p switch is used and the -r switch is not.\n"
    1718             : );
    1719             :   printf(
    1720             : "    -c  Creates segments on the convex hull of the triangulation.  If you\n");
    1721             :   printf(
    1722             : "        are triangulating a vertex set, this switch causes a .poly file to\n"
    1723             : );
    1724             :   printf(
    1725             : "        be written, containing all edges of the convex hull.  If you are\n");
    1726             :   printf(
    1727             : "        triangulating a PSLG, this switch specifies that the whole convex\n");
    1728             :   printf(
    1729             : "        hull of the PSLG should be triangulated, regardless of what\n");
    1730             :   printf(
    1731             : "        segments the PSLG has.  If you do not use this switch when\n");
    1732             :   printf(
    1733             : "        triangulating a PSLG, Triangle assumes that you have identified the\n"
    1734             : );
    1735             :   printf(
    1736             : "        region to be triangulated by surrounding it with segments of the\n");
    1737             :   printf(
    1738             : "        input PSLG.  Beware:  if you are not careful, this switch can cause\n"
    1739             : );
    1740             :   printf(
    1741             : "        the introduction of an extremely thin angle between a PSLG segment\n"
    1742             : );
    1743             :   printf(
    1744             : "        and a convex hull segment, which can cause overrefinement (and\n");
    1745             :   printf(
    1746             : "        possibly failure if Triangle runs out of precision).  If you are\n");
    1747             :   printf(
    1748             : "        refining a mesh, the -c switch works differently:  it causes a\n");
    1749             :   printf(
    1750             : "        .poly file to be written containing the boundary edges of the mesh\n"
    1751             : );
    1752             :   printf("        (useful if no .poly file was read).\n");
    1753             :   printf(
    1754             : "    -D  Conforming Delaunay triangulation:  use this switch if you want to\n"
    1755             : );
    1756             :   printf(
    1757             : "        ensure that all the triangles in the mesh are Delaunay, and not\n");
    1758             :   printf(
    1759             : "        merely constrained Delaunay; or if you want to ensure that all the\n"
    1760             : );
    1761             :   printf(
    1762             : "        Voronoi vertices lie within the triangulation.  (Some finite volume\n"
    1763             : );
    1764             :   printf(
    1765             : "        methods have this requirement.)  This switch invokes Ruppert's\n");
    1766             :   printf(
    1767             : "        original algorithm, which splits every subsegment whose diametral\n");
    1768             :   printf(
    1769             : "        circle is encroached.  It usually increases the number of vertices\n"
    1770             : );
    1771             :   printf("        and triangles.\n");
    1772             :   printf(
    1773             : "    -j  Jettisons vertices that are not part of the final triangulation\n");
    1774             :   printf(
    1775             : "        from the output .node file.  By default, Triangle copies all\n");
    1776             :   printf(
    1777             : "        vertices in the input .node file to the output .node file, in the\n");
    1778             :   printf(
    1779             : "        same order, so their indices do not change.  The -j switch prevents\n"
    1780             : );
    1781             :   printf(
    1782             : "        duplicated input vertices, or vertices `eaten' by holes, from\n");
    1783             :   printf(
    1784             : "        appearing in the output .node file.  Thus, if two input vertices\n");
    1785             :   printf(
    1786             : "        have exactly the same coordinates, only the first appears in the\n");
    1787             :   printf(
    1788             : "        output.  If any vertices are jettisoned, the vertex numbering in\n");
    1789             :   printf(
    1790             : "        the output .node file differs from that of the input .node file.\n");
    1791             :   printf(
    1792             : "    -e  Outputs (to an .edge file) a list of edges of the triangulation.\n");
    1793             :   printf(
    1794             : "    -v  Outputs the Voronoi diagram associated with the triangulation.\n");
    1795             :   printf(
    1796             : "        Does not attempt to detect degeneracies, so some Voronoi vertices\n");
    1797             :   printf(
    1798             : "        may be duplicated.  See the discussion of Voronoi diagrams below.\n");
    1799             :   printf(
    1800             : "    -n  Outputs (to a .neigh file) a list of triangles neighboring each\n");
    1801             :   printf("        triangle.\n");
    1802             :   printf(
    1803             : "    -g  Outputs the mesh to an Object File Format (.off) file, suitable for\n"
    1804             : );
    1805             :   printf("        viewing with the Geometry Center's Geomview package.\n");
    1806             :   printf(
    1807             : "    -B  No boundary markers in the output .node, .poly, and .edge output\n");
    1808             :   printf(
    1809             : "        files.  See the detailed discussion of boundary markers below.\n");
    1810             :   printf(
    1811             : "    -P  No output .poly file.  Saves disk space, but you lose the ability\n");
    1812             :   printf(
    1813             : "        to maintain constraining segments on later refinements of the mesh.\n"
    1814             : );
    1815             :   printf("    -N  No output .node file.\n");
    1816             :   printf("    -E  No output .ele file.\n");
    1817             :   printf(
    1818             : "    -I  No iteration numbers.  Suppresses the output of .node and .poly\n");
    1819             :   printf(
    1820             : "        files, so your input files won't be overwritten.  (If your input is\n"
    1821             : );
    1822             :   printf(
    1823             : "        a .poly file only, a .node file is written.)  Cannot be used with\n");
    1824             :   printf(
    1825             : "        the -r switch, because that would overwrite your input .ele file.\n");
    1826             :   printf(
    1827             : "        Shouldn't be used with the -q, -a, -u, or -s switch if you are\n");
    1828             :   printf(
    1829             : "        using a .node file for input, because no .node file is written, so\n"
    1830             : );
    1831             :   printf("        there is no record of any added Steiner points.\n");
    1832             :   printf("    -O  No holes.  Ignores the holes in the .poly file.\n");
    1833             :   printf(
    1834             : "    -X  No exact arithmetic.  Normally, Triangle uses exact floating-point\n"
    1835             : );
    1836             :   printf(
    1837             : "        arithmetic for certain tests if it thinks the inexact tests are not\n"
    1838             : );
    1839             :   printf(
    1840             : "        accurate enough.  Exact arithmetic ensures the robustness of the\n");
    1841             :   printf(
    1842             : "        triangulation algorithms, despite floating-point roundoff error.\n");
    1843             :   printf(
    1844             : "        Disabling exact arithmetic with the -X switch causes a small\n");
    1845             :   printf(
    1846             : "        improvement in speed and creates the possibility that Triangle will\n"
    1847             : );
    1848             :   printf("        fail to produce a valid mesh.  Not recommended.\n");
    1849             :   printf(
    1850             : "    -z  Numbers all items starting from zero (rather than one).  Note that\n"
    1851             : );
    1852             :   printf(
    1853             : "        this switch is normally overridden by the value used to number the\n"
    1854             : );
    1855             :   printf(
    1856             : "        first vertex of the input .node or .poly file.  However, this\n");
    1857             :   printf(
    1858             : "        switch is useful when calling Triangle from another program.\n");
    1859             :   printf(
    1860             : "    -o2 Generates second-order subparametric elements with six nodes each.\n"
    1861             : );
    1862             :   printf(
    1863             : "    -Y  No new vertices on the boundary.  This switch is useful when the\n");
    1864             :   printf(
    1865             : "        mesh boundary must be preserved so that it conforms to some\n");
    1866             :   printf(
    1867             : "        adjacent mesh.  Be forewarned that you will probably sacrifice much\n"
    1868             : );
    1869             :   printf(
    1870             : "        of the quality of the mesh; Triangle will try, but the resulting\n");
    1871             :   printf(
    1872             : "        mesh may contain poorly shaped triangles.  Works well if all the\n");
    1873             :   printf(
    1874             : "        boundary vertices are closely spaced.  Specify this switch twice\n");
    1875             :   printf(
    1876             : "        (`-YY') to prevent all segment splitting, including internal\n");
    1877             :   printf("        boundaries.\n");
    1878             :   printf(
    1879             : "    -S  Specifies the maximum number of Steiner points (vertices that are\n");
    1880             :   printf(
    1881             : "        not in the input, but are added to meet the constraints on minimum\n"
    1882             : );
    1883             :   printf(
    1884             : "        angle and maximum area).  The default is to allow an unlimited\n");
    1885             :   printf(
    1886             : "        number.  If you specify this switch with no number after it,\n");
    1887             :   printf(
    1888             : "        the limit is set to zero.  Triangle always adds vertices at segment\n"
    1889             : );
    1890             :   printf(
    1891             : "        intersections, even if it needs to use more vertices than the limit\n"
    1892             : );
    1893             :   printf(
    1894             : "        you set.  When Triangle inserts segments by splitting (-s), it\n");
    1895             :   printf(
    1896             : "        always adds enough vertices to ensure that all the segments of the\n"
    1897             : );
    1898             :   printf("        PLSG are recovered, ignoring the limit if necessary.\n");
    1899             :   printf(
    1900             : "    -i  Uses an incremental rather than a divide-and-conquer algorithm to\n");
    1901             :   printf(
    1902             : "        construct a Delaunay triangulation.  Try it if the divide-and-\n");
    1903             :   printf("        conquer algorithm fails.\n");
    1904             :   printf(
    1905             : "    -F  Uses Steven Fortune's sweepline algorithm to construct a Delaunay\n");
    1906             :   printf(
    1907             : "        triangulation.  Warning:  does not use exact arithmetic for all\n");
    1908             :   printf("        calculations.  An exact result is not guaranteed.\n");
    1909             :   printf(
    1910             : "    -l  Uses only vertical cuts in the divide-and-conquer algorithm.  By\n");
    1911             :   printf(
    1912             : "        default, Triangle alternates between vertical and horizontal cuts,\n"
    1913             : );
    1914             :   printf(
    1915             : "        which usually improve the speed except with vertex sets that are\n");
    1916             :   printf(
    1917             : "        small or short and wide.  This switch is primarily of theoretical\n");
    1918             :   printf("        interest.\n");
    1919             :   printf(
    1920             : "    -s  Specifies that segments should be forced into the triangulation by\n"
    1921             : );
    1922             :   printf(
    1923             : "        recursively splitting them at their midpoints, rather than by\n");
    1924             :   printf(
    1925             : "        generating a constrained Delaunay triangulation.  Segment splitting\n"
    1926             : );
    1927             :   printf(
    1928             : "        is true to Ruppert's original algorithm, but can create needlessly\n"
    1929             : );
    1930             :   printf(
    1931             : "        small triangles.  This switch is primarily of theoretical interest.\n"
    1932             : );
    1933             :   printf(
    1934             : "    -C  Check the consistency of the final mesh.  Uses exact arithmetic for\n"
    1935             : );
    1936             :   printf(
    1937             : "        checking, even if the -X switch is used.  Useful if you suspect\n");
    1938             :   printf("        Triangle is buggy.\n");
    1939             :   printf(
    1940             : "    -Q  Quiet:  Suppresses all explanation of what Triangle is doing,\n");
    1941             :   printf("        unless an error occurs.\n");
    1942             :   printf(
    1943             : "    -V  Verbose:  Gives detailed information about what Triangle is doing.\n"
    1944             : );
    1945             :   printf(
    1946             : "        Add more `V's for increasing amount of detail.  `-V' is most\n");
    1947             :   printf(
    1948             : "        useful; itgives information on algorithmic progress and much more\n");
    1949             :   printf(
    1950             : "        detailed statistics.  `-VV' gives vertex-by-vertex details, and\n");
    1951             :   printf(
    1952             : "        prints so much that Triangle runs much more slowly.  `-VVVV' gives\n"
    1953             : );
    1954             :   printf("        information only a debugger could love.\n");
    1955             :   printf("    -h  Help:  Displays these instructions.\n");
    1956             :   printf("\n");
    1957             :   printf("Definitions:\n");
    1958             :   printf("\n");
    1959             :   printf(
    1960             : "  A Delaunay triangulation of a vertex set is a triangulation whose\n");
    1961             :   printf(
    1962             : "  vertices are the vertex set, that covers the convex hull of the vertex\n");
    1963             :   printf(
    1964             : "  set.  A Delaunay triangulation has the property that no vertex lies\n");
    1965             :   printf(
    1966             : "  inside the circumscribing circle (circle that passes through all three\n");
    1967             :   printf("  vertices) of any triangle in the triangulation.\n\n");
    1968             :   printf(
    1969             : "  A Voronoi diagram of a vertex set is a subdivision of the plane into\n");
    1970             :   printf(
    1971             : "  polygonal cells (some of which may be unbounded, meaning infinitely\n");
    1972             :   printf(
    1973             : "  large), where each cell is the set of points in the plane that are closer\n"
    1974             : );
    1975             :   printf(
    1976             : "  to some input vertex than to any other input vertex.  The Voronoi diagram\n"
    1977             : );
    1978             :   printf("  is a geometric dual of the Delaunay triangulation.\n\n");
    1979             :   printf(
    1980             : "  A Planar Straight Line Graph (PSLG) is a set of vertices and segments.\n");
    1981             :   printf(
    1982             : "  Segments are simply edges, whose endpoints are all vertices in the PSLG.\n"
    1983             : );
    1984             :   printf(
    1985             : "  Segments may intersect each other only at their endpoints.  The file\n");
    1986             :   printf("  format for PSLGs (.poly files) is described below.\n\n");
    1987             :   printf(
    1988             : "  A constrained Delaunay triangulation (CDT) of a PSLG is similar to a\n");
    1989             :   printf(
    1990             : "  Delaunay triangulation, but each PSLG segment is present as a single edge\n"
    1991             : );
    1992             :   printf(
    1993             : "  of the CDT.  (A constrained Delaunay triangulation is not truly a\n");
    1994             :   printf(
    1995             : "  Delaunay triangulation, because some of its triangles might not be\n");
    1996             :   printf(
    1997             : "  Delaunay.)  By definition, a CDT does not have any vertices other than\n");
    1998             :   printf(
    1999             : "  those specified in the input PSLG.  Depending on context, a CDT might\n");
    2000             :   printf(
    2001             : "  cover the convex hull of the PSLG, or it might cover only a segment-\n");
    2002             :   printf("  bounded region (e.g. a polygon).\n\n");
    2003             :   printf(
    2004             : "  A conforming Delaunay triangulation of a PSLG is a triangulation in which\n"
    2005             : );
    2006             :   printf(
    2007             : "  each triangle is truly Delaunay, and each PSLG segment is represented by\n"
    2008             : );
    2009             :   printf(
    2010             : "  a linear contiguous sequence of edges of the triangulation.  New vertices\n"
    2011             : );
    2012             :   printf(
    2013             : "  (not part of the PSLG) may appear, and each input segment may have been\n");
    2014             :   printf(
    2015             : "  subdivided into shorter edges (subsegments) by these additional vertices.\n"
    2016             : );
    2017             :   printf(
    2018             : "  The new vertices are frequently necessary to maintain the Delaunay\n");
    2019             :   printf("  property while ensuring that every segment is represented.\n\n");
    2020             :   printf(
    2021             : "  A conforming constrained Delaunay triangulation (CCDT) of a PSLG is a\n");
    2022             :   printf(
    2023             : "  triangulation of a PSLG whose triangles are constrained Delaunay.  New\n");
    2024             :   printf("  vertices may appear, and input segments may be subdivided into\n");
    2025             :   printf(
    2026             : "  subsegments, but not to guarantee that segments are respected; rather, to\n"
    2027             : );
    2028             :   printf(
    2029             : "  improve the quality of the triangles.  The high-quality meshes produced\n");
    2030             :   printf(
    2031             : "  by the -q switch are usually CCDTs, but can be made conforming Delaunay\n");
    2032             :   printf("  with the -D switch.\n\n");
    2033             :   printf("File Formats:\n\n");
    2034             :   printf(
    2035             : "  All files may contain comments prefixed by the character '#'.  Vertices,\n"
    2036             : );
    2037             :   printf(
    2038             : "  triangles, edges, holes, and maximum area constraints must be numbered\n");
    2039             :   printf(
    2040             : "  consecutively, starting from either 1 or 0.  Whichever you choose, all\n");
    2041             :   printf(
    2042             : "  input files must be consistent; if the vertices are numbered from 1, so\n");
    2043             :   printf(
    2044             : "  must be all other objects.  Triangle automatically detects your choice\n");
    2045             :   printf(
    2046             : "  while reading the .node (or .poly) file.  (When calling Triangle from\n");
    2047             :   printf(
    2048             : "  another program, use the -z switch if you wish to number objects from\n");
    2049             :   printf("  zero.)  Examples of these file formats are given below.\n\n");
    2050             :   printf("  .node files:\n");
    2051             :   printf(
    2052             : "    First line:  <# of vertices> <dimension (must be 2)> <# of attributes>\n"
    2053             : );
    2054             :   printf(
    2055             : "                                           <# of boundary markers (0 or 1)>\n"
    2056             : );
    2057             :   printf(
    2058             : "    Remaining lines:  <vertex #> <x> <y> [attributes] [boundary marker]\n");
    2059             :   printf("\n");
    2060             :   printf(
    2061             : "    The attributes, which are typically floating-point values of physical\n");
    2062             :   printf(
    2063             : "    quantities (such as mass or conductivity) associated with the nodes of\n"
    2064             : );
    2065             :   printf(
    2066             : "    a finite element mesh, are copied unchanged to the output mesh.  If -q,\n"
    2067             : );
    2068             :   printf(
    2069             : "    -a, -u, -D, or -s is selected, each new Steiner point added to the mesh\n"
    2070             : );
    2071             :   printf("    has attributes assigned to it by linear interpolation.\n\n");
    2072             :   printf(
    2073             : "    If the fourth entry of the first line is `1', the last column of the\n");
    2074             :   printf(
    2075             : "    remainder of the file is assumed to contain boundary markers.  Boundary\n"
    2076             : );
    2077             :   printf(
    2078             : "    markers are used to identify boundary vertices and vertices resting on\n"
    2079             : );
    2080             :   printf(
    2081             : "    PSLG segments; a complete description appears in a section below.  The\n"
    2082             : );
    2083             :   printf(
    2084             : "    .node file produced by Triangle contains boundary markers in the last\n");
    2085             :   printf("    column unless they are suppressed by the -B switch.\n\n");
    2086             :   printf("  .ele files:\n");
    2087             :   printf(
    2088             : "    First line:  <# of triangles> <nodes per triangle> <# of attributes>\n");
    2089             :   printf(
    2090             : "    Remaining lines:  <triangle #> <node> <node> <node> ... [attributes]\n");
    2091             :   printf("\n");
    2092             :   printf(
    2093             : "    Nodes are indices into the corresponding .node file.  The first three\n");
    2094             :   printf(
    2095             : "    nodes are the corner vertices, and are listed in counterclockwise order\n"
    2096             : );
    2097             :   printf(
    2098             : "    around each triangle.  (The remaining nodes, if any, depend on the type\n"
    2099             : );
    2100             :   printf("    of finite element used.)\n\n");
    2101             :   printf(
    2102             : "    The attributes are just like those of .node files.  Because there is no\n"
    2103             : );
    2104             :   printf(
    2105             : "    simple mapping from input to output triangles, Triangle attempts to\n");
    2106             :   printf(
    2107             : "    interpolate attributes, and may cause a lot of diffusion of attributes\n"
    2108             : );
    2109             :   printf(
    2110             : "    among nearby triangles as the triangulation is refined.  Attributes do\n"
    2111             : );
    2112             :   printf("    not diffuse across segments, so attributes used to identify\n");
    2113             :   printf("    segment-bounded regions remain intact.\n\n");
    2114             :   printf(
    2115             : "    In .ele files produced by Triangle, each triangular element has three\n");
    2116             :   printf(
    2117             : "    nodes (vertices) unless the -o2 switch is used, in which case\n");
    2118             :   printf(
    2119             : "    subparametric quadratic elements with six nodes each are generated.\n");
    2120             :   printf(
    2121             : "    The first three nodes are the corners in counterclockwise order, and\n");
    2122             :   printf(
    2123             : "    the fourth, fifth, and sixth nodes lie on the midpoints of the edges\n");
    2124             :   printf(
    2125             : "    opposite the first, second, and third vertices, respectively.\n");
    2126             :   printf("\n");
    2127             :   printf("  .poly files:\n");
    2128             :   printf(
    2129             : "    First line:  <# of vertices> <dimension (must be 2)> <# of attributes>\n"
    2130             : );
    2131             :   printf(
    2132             : "                                           <# of boundary markers (0 or 1)>\n"
    2133             : );
    2134             :   printf(
    2135             : "    Following lines:  <vertex #> <x> <y> [attributes] [boundary marker]\n");
    2136             :   printf("    One line:  <# of segments> <# of boundary markers (0 or 1)>\n");
    2137             :   printf(
    2138             : "    Following lines:  <segment #> <endpoint> <endpoint> [boundary marker]\n");
    2139             :   printf("    One line:  <# of holes>\n");
    2140             :   printf("    Following lines:  <hole #> <x> <y>\n");
    2141             :   printf(
    2142             : "    Optional line:  <# of regional attributes and/or area constraints>\n");
    2143             :   printf(
    2144             : "    Optional following lines:  <region #> <x> <y> <attribute> <max area>\n");
    2145             :   printf("\n");
    2146             :   printf(
    2147             : "    A .poly file represents a PSLG, as well as some additional information.\n"
    2148             : );
    2149             :   printf(
    2150             : "    The first section lists all the vertices, and is identical to the\n");
    2151             :   printf(
    2152             : "    format of .node files.  <# of vertices> may be set to zero to indicate\n"
    2153             : );
    2154             :   printf(
    2155             : "    that the vertices are listed in a separate .node file; .poly files\n");
    2156             :   printf(
    2157             : "    produced by Triangle always have this format.  A vertex set represented\n"
    2158             : );
    2159             :   printf(
    2160             : "    this way has the advantage that it may easily be triangulated with or\n");
    2161             :   printf(
    2162             : "    without segments (depending on whether the -p switch is invoked).\n");
    2163             :   printf("\n");
    2164             :   printf(
    2165             : "    The second section lists the segments.  Segments are edges whose\n");
    2166             :   printf(
    2167             : "    presence in the triangulation is enforced.  (Depending on the choice of\n"
    2168             : );
    2169             :   printf(
    2170             : "    switches, segment might be subdivided into smaller edges).  Each\n");
    2171             :   printf(
