    2172             : "    segment is specified by listing the indices of its two endpoints.  This\n"
    2173             : );
    2174             :   printf(
    2175             : "    means that you must include its endpoints in the vertex list.  Each\n");
    2176             :   printf("    segment, like each point, may have a boundary marker.\n\n");
    2177             :   printf(
    2178             : "    If -q, -a, -u, and -s are not selected, Triangle produces a constrained\n"
    2179             : );
    2180             :   printf(
    2181             : "    Delaunay triangulation (CDT), in which each segment appears as a single\n"
    2182             : );
    2183             :   printf(
    2184             : "    edge in the triangulation.  If -q, -a, -u, or -s is selected, Triangle\n"
    2185             : );
    2186             :   printf(
    2187             : "    produces a conforming constrained Delaunay triangulation (CCDT), in\n");
    2188             :   printf(
    2189             : "    which segments may be subdivided into smaller edges.  If -D is\n");
    2190             :   printf(
    2191             : "    selected, Triangle produces a conforming Delaunay triangulation, so\n");
    2192             :   printf(
    2193             : "    that every triangle is Delaunay, and not just constrained Delaunay.\n");
    2194             :   printf("\n");
    2195             :   printf(
    2196             : "    The third section lists holes (and concavities, if -c is selected) in\n");
    2197             :   printf(
    2198             : "    the triangulation.  Holes are specified by identifying a point inside\n");
    2199             :   printf(
    2200             : "    each hole.  After the triangulation is formed, Triangle creates holes\n");
    2201             :   printf(
    2202             : "    by eating triangles, spreading out from each hole point until its\n");
    2203             :   printf(
    2204             : "    progress is blocked by segments in the PSLG.  You must be careful to\n");
    2205             :   printf(
    2206             : "    enclose each hole in segments, or your whole triangulation might be\n");
    2207             :   printf(
    2208             : "    eaten away.  If the two triangles abutting a segment are eaten, the\n");
    2209             :   printf(
    2210             : "    segment itself is also eaten.  Do not place a hole directly on a\n");
    2211             :   printf("    segment; if you do, Triangle chooses one side of the segment\n");
    2212             :   printf("    arbitrarily.\n\n");
    2213             :   printf(
    2214             : "    The optional fourth section lists regional attributes (to be assigned\n");
    2215             :   printf(
    2216             : "    to all triangles in a region) and regional constraints on the maximum\n");
    2217             :   printf(
    2218             : "    triangle area.  Triangle reads this section only if the -A switch is\n");
    2219             :   printf(
    2220             : "    used or the -a switch is used without a number following it, and the -r\n"
    2221             : );
    2222             :   printf(
    2223             : "    switch is not used.  Regional attributes and area constraints are\n");
    2224             :   printf(
    2225             : "    propagated in the same manner as holes:  you specify a point for each\n");
    2226             :   printf(
    2227             : "    attribute and/or constraint, and the attribute and/or constraint\n");
    2228             :   printf(
    2229             : "    affects the whole region (bounded by segments) containing the point.\n");
    2230             :   printf(
    2231             : "    If two values are written on a line after the x and y coordinate, the\n");
    2232             :   printf(
    2233             : "    first such value is assumed to be a regional attribute (but is only\n");
    2234             :   printf(
    2235             : "    applied if the -A switch is selected), and the second value is assumed\n"
    2236             : );
    2237             :   printf(
    2238             : "    to be a regional area constraint (but is only applied if the -a switch\n"
    2239             : );
    2240             :   printf(
    2241             : "    is selected).  You may specify just one value after the coordinates,\n");
    2242             :   printf(
    2243             : "    which can serve as both an attribute and an area constraint, depending\n"
    2244             : );
    2245             :   printf(
    2246             : "    on the choice of switches.  If you are using the -A and -a switches\n");
    2247             :   printf(
    2248             : "    simultaneously and wish to assign an attribute to some region without\n");
    2249             :   printf("    imposing an area constraint, use a negative maximum area.\n\n");
    2250             :   printf(
    2251             : "    When a triangulation is created from a .poly file, you must either\n");
    2252             :   printf(
    2253             : "    enclose the entire region to be triangulated in PSLG segments, or\n");
    2254             :   printf(
    2255             : "    use the -c switch, which automatically creates extra segments that\n");
    2256             :   printf(
    2257             : "    enclose the convex hull of the PSLG.  If you do not use the -c switch,\n"
    2258             : );
    2259             :   printf(
    2260             : "    Triangle eats all triangles that are not enclosed by segments; if you\n");
    2261             :   printf(
    2262             : "    are not careful, your whole triangulation may be eaten away.  If you do\n"
    2263             : );
    2264             :   printf(
    2265             : "    use the -c switch, you can still produce concavities by the appropriate\n"
    2266             : );
    2267             :   printf(
    2268             : "    placement of holes just inside the boundary of the convex hull.\n");
    2269             :   printf("\n");
    2270             :   printf(
    2271             : "    An ideal PSLG has no intersecting segments, nor any vertices that lie\n");
    2272             :   printf(
    2273             : "    upon segments (except, of course, the endpoints of each segment).  You\n"
    2274             : );
    2275             :   printf(
    2276             : "    aren't required to make your .poly files ideal, but you should be aware\n"
    2277             : );
    2278             :   printf(
    2279             : "    of what can go wrong.  Segment intersections are relatively safe--\n");
    2280             :   printf(
    2281             : "    Triangle calculates the intersection points for you and adds them to\n");
    2282             :   printf(
    2283             : "    the triangulation--as ptrdiff_t  as your machine's floating-point precision\n");
    2284             :   printf(
    2285             : "    doesn't become a problem.  You are tempting the fates if you have three\n"
    2286             : );
    2287             :   printf(
    2288             : "    segments that cross at the same location, and expect Triangle to figure\n"
    2289             : );
    2290             :   printf(
    2291             : "    out where the intersection point is.  Thanks to floating-point roundoff\n"
    2292             : );
    2293             :   printf(
    2294             : "    error, Triangle will probably decide that the three segments intersect\n"
    2295             : );
    2296             :   printf(
    2297             : "    at three different points, and you will find a minuscule triangle in\n");
    2298             :   printf(
    2299             : "    your output--unless Triangle tries to refine the tiny triangle, uses\n");
    2300             :   printf(
    2301             : "    up the last bit of machine precision, and fails to terminate at all.\n");
    2302             :   printf(
    2303             : "    You're better off putting the intersection point in the input files,\n");
    2304             :   printf(
    2305             : "    and manually breaking up each segment into two.  Similarly, if you\n");
    2306             :   printf(
    2307             : "    place a vertex at the middle of a segment, and hope that Triangle will\n"
    2308             : );
    2309             :   printf(
    2310             : "    break up the segment at that vertex, you might get lucky.  On the other\n"
    2311             : );
    2312             :   printf(
    2313             : "    hand, Triangle might decide that the vertex doesn't lie precisely on\n");
    2314             :   printf(
    2315             : "    the segment, and you'll have a needle-sharp triangle in your output--or\n"
    2316             : );
    2317             :   printf("    a lot of tiny triangles if you're generating a quality mesh.\n");
    2318             :   printf("\n");
    2319             :   printf(
    2320             : "    When Triangle reads a .poly file, it also writes a .poly file, which\n");
    2321             :   printf(
    2322             : "    includes all the subsegments--the edges that are parts of input\n");
    2323             :   printf(
    2324             : "    segments.  If the -c switch is used, the output .poly file also\n");
    2325             :   printf(
    2326             : "    includes all of the edges on the convex hull.  Hence, the output .poly\n"
    2327             : );
    2328             :   printf(
    2329             : "    file is useful for finding edges associated with input segments and for\n"
    2330             : );
    2331             :   printf(
    2332             : "    setting boundary conditions in finite element simulations.  Moreover,\n");
    2333             :   printf(
    2334             : "    you will need the output .poly file if you plan to refine the output\n");
    2335             :   printf(
    2336             : "    mesh, and don't want segments to be missing in later triangulations.\n");
    2337             :   printf("\n");
    2338             :   printf("  .area files:\n");
    2339             :   printf("    First line:  <# of triangles>\n");
    2340             :   printf("    Following lines:  <triangle #> <maximum area>\n");
    2341             :   printf("\n");
    2342             :   printf(
    2343             : "    An .area file associates with each triangle a maximum area that is used\n"
    2344             : );
    2345             :   printf(
    2346             : "    for mesh refinement.  As with other file formats, every triangle must\n");
    2347             :   printf(
    2348             : "    be represented, and the triangles must be numbered consecutively.  A\n");
    2349             :   printf(
    2350             : "    triangle may be left unconstrained by assigning it a negative maximum\n");
    2351             :   printf("    area.\n\n");
    2352             :   printf("  .edge files:\n");
    2353             :   printf("    First line:  <# of edges> <# of boundary markers (0 or 1)>\n");
    2354             :   printf(
    2355             : "    Following lines:  <edge #> <endpoint> <endpoint> [boundary marker]\n");
    2356             :   printf("\n");
    2357             :   printf(
    2358             : "    Endpoints are indices into the corresponding .node file.  Triangle can\n"
    2359             : );
    2360             :   printf(
    2361             : "    produce .edge files (use the -e switch), but cannot read them.  The\n");
    2362             :   printf(
    2363             : "    optional column of boundary markers is suppressed by the -B switch.\n");
    2364             :   printf("\n");
    2365             :   printf(
    2366             : "    In Voronoi diagrams, one also finds a special kind of edge that is an\n");
    2367             :   printf(
    2368             : "    infinite ray with only one endpoint.  For these edges, a different\n");
    2369             :   printf("    format is used:\n\n");
    2370             :   printf("        <edge #> <endpoint> -1 <direction x> <direction y>\n\n");
    2371             :   printf(
    2372             : "    The `direction' is a floating-point vector that indicates the direction\n"
    2373             : );
    2374             :   printf("    of the infinite ray.\n\n");
    2375             :   printf("  .neigh files:\n");
    2376             :   printf(
    2377             : "    First line:  <# of triangles> <# of neighbors per triangle (always 3)>\n"
    2378             : );
    2379             :   printf(
    2380             : "    Following lines:  <triangle #> <neighbor> <neighbor> <neighbor>\n");
    2381             :   printf("\n");
    2382             :   printf(
    2383             : "    Neighbors are indices into the corresponding .ele file.  An index of -1\n"
    2384             : );
    2385             :   printf(
    2386             : "    indicates no neighbor (because the triangle is on an exterior\n");
    2387             :   printf(
    2388             : "    boundary).  The first neighbor of triangle i is opposite the first\n");
    2389             :   printf("    corner of triangle i, and so on.\n\n");
    2390             :   printf(
    2391             : "    Triangle can produce .neigh files (use the -n switch), but cannot read\n"
    2392             : );
    2393             :   printf("    them.\n\n");
    2394             :   printf("Boundary Markers:\n\n");
    2395             :   printf(
    2396             : "  Boundary markers are tags used mainly to identify which output vertices\n");
    2397             :   printf(
    2398             : "  and edges are associated with which PSLG segment, and to identify which\n");
    2399             :   printf(
    2400             : "  vertices and edges occur on a boundary of the triangulation.  A common\n");
    2401             :   printf(
    2402             : "  use is to determine where boundary conditions should be applied to a\n");
    2403             :   printf(
    2404             : "  finite element mesh.  You can prevent boundary markers from being written\n"
    2405             : );
    2406             :   printf("  into files produced by Triangle by using the -B switch.\n\n");
    2407             :   printf(
    2408             : "  The boundary marker associated with each segment in an output .poly file\n"
    2409             : );
    2410             :   printf("  and each edge in an output .edge file is chosen as follows:\n");
    2411             :   printf(
    2412             : "    - If an output edge is part or all of a PSLG segment with a nonzero\n");
    2413             :   printf(
    2414             : "      boundary marker, then the edge is assigned the same marker.\n");
    2415             :   printf(
    2416             : "    - Otherwise, if the edge lies on a boundary of the triangulation\n");
    2417             :   printf(
    2418             : "      (even the boundary of a hole), then the edge is assigned the marker\n");
    2419             :   printf("      one (1).\n");
    2420             :   printf("    - Otherwise, the edge is assigned the marker zero (0).\n");
    2421             :   printf(
    2422             : "  The boundary marker associated with each vertex in an output .node file\n");
    2423             :   printf("  is chosen as follows:\n");
    2424             :   printf(
    2425             : "    - If a vertex is assigned a nonzero boundary marker in the input file,\n"
    2426             : );
    2427             :   printf(
    2428             : "      then it is assigned the same marker in the output .node file.\n");
    2429             :   printf(
    2430             : "    - Otherwise, if the vertex lies on a PSLG segment (even if it is an\n");
    2431             :   printf(
    2432             : "      endpoint of the segment) with a nonzero boundary marker, then the\n");
    2433             :   printf(
    2434             : "      vertex is assigned the same marker.  If the vertex lies on several\n");
    2435             :   printf("      such segments, one of the markers is chosen arbitrarily.\n");
    2436             :   printf(
    2437             : "    - Otherwise, if the vertex occurs on a boundary of the triangulation,\n");
    2438             :   printf("      then the vertex is assigned the marker one (1).\n");
    2439             :   printf("    - Otherwise, the vertex is assigned the marker zero (0).\n");
    2440             :   printf("\n");
    2441             :   printf(
    2442             : "  If you want Triangle to determine for you which vertices and edges are on\n"
    2443             : );
    2444             :   printf(
    2445             : "  the boundary, assign them the boundary marker zero (or use no markers at\n"
    2446             : );
    2447             :   printf(
    2448             : "  all) in your input files.  In the output files, all boundary vertices,\n");
    2449             :   printf("  edges, and segments will be assigned the value one.\n\n");
    2450             :   printf("Triangulation Iteration Numbers:\n\n");
    2451             :   printf(
    2452             : "  Because Triangle can read and refine its own triangulations, input\n");
    2453             :   printf(
    2454             : "  and output files have iteration numbers.  For instance, Triangle might\n");
    2455             :   printf(
    2456             : "  read the files mesh.3.node, mesh.3.ele, and mesh.3.poly, refine the\n");
    2457             :   printf(
    2458             : "  triangulation, and output the files mesh.4.node, mesh.4.ele, and\n");
    2459             :   printf("  mesh.4.poly.  Files with no iteration number are treated as if\n");
    2460             :   printf(
    2461             : "  their iteration number is zero; hence, Triangle might read the file\n");
    2462             :   printf(
    2463             : "  points.node, triangulate it, and produce the files points.1.node and\n");
    2464             :   printf("  points.1.ele.\n\n");
    2465             :   printf(
    2466             : "  Iteration numbers allow you to create a sequence of successively finer\n");
    2467             :   printf(
    2468             : "  meshes suitable for multigrid methods.  They also allow you to produce a\n"
    2469             : );
    2470             :   printf(
    2471             : "  sequence of meshes using error estimate-driven mesh refinement.\n");
    2472             :   printf("\n");
    2473             :   printf(
    2474             : "  If you're not using refinement or quality meshing, and you don't like\n");
    2475             :   printf(
    2476             : "  iteration numbers, use the -I switch to disable them.  This switch also\n");
    2477             :   printf(
    2478             : "  disables output of .node and .poly files to prevent your input files from\n"
    2479             : );
    2480             :   printf(
    2481             : "  being overwritten.  (If the input is a .poly file that contains its own\n");
    2482             :   printf(
    2483             : "  points, a .node file is written.  This can be quite convenient for\n");
    2484             :   printf("  computing CDTs or quality meshes.)\n\n");
    2485             :   printf("Examples of How to Use Triangle:\n\n");
    2486             :   printf(
    2487             : "  `triangle dots' reads vertices from dots.node, and writes their Delaunay\n"
    2488             : );
    2489             :   printf(
    2490             : "  triangulation to dots.1.node and dots.1.ele.  (dots.1.node is identical\n");
    2491             :   printf(
    2492             : "  to dots.node.)  `triangle -I dots' writes the triangulation to dots.ele\n");
    2493             :   printf(
    2494             : "  instead.  (No additional .node file is needed, so none is written.)\n");
    2495             :   printf("\n");
    2496             :   printf(
    2497             : "  `triangle -pe object.1' reads a PSLG from object.1.poly (and possibly\n");
    2498             :   printf(
    2499             : "  object.1.node, if the vertices are omitted from object.1.poly) and writes\n"
    2500             : );
    2501             :   printf(
    2502             : "  its constrained Delaunay triangulation to object.2.node and object.2.ele.\n"
    2503             : );
    2504             :   printf(
    2505             : "  The segments are copied to object.2.poly, and all edges are written to\n");
    2506             :   printf("  object.2.edge.\n\n");
    2507             :   printf(
    2508             : "  `triangle -pq31.5a.1 object' reads a PSLG from object.poly (and possibly\n"
    2509             : );
    2510             :   printf(
    2511             : "  object.node), generates a mesh whose angles are all between 31.5 and 117\n"
    2512             : );
    2513             :   printf(
    2514             : "  degrees and whose triangles all have areas of 0.1 or less, and writes the\n"
    2515             : );
    2516             :   printf(
    2517             : "  mesh to object.1.node and object.1.ele.  Each segment may be broken up\n");
    2518             :   printf("  into multiple subsegments; these are written to object.1.poly.\n");
    2519             :   printf("\n");
    2520             :   printf(
    2521             : "  Here is a sample file `box.poly' describing a square with a square hole:\n"
    2522             : );
    2523             :   printf("\n");
    2524             :   printf(
    2525             : "    # A box with eight vertices in 2D, no attributes, one boundary marker.\n"
    2526             : );
    2527             :   printf("    8 2 0 1\n");
    2528             :   printf("     # Outer box has these vertices:\n");
    2529             :   printf("     1   0 0   0\n");
    2530             :   printf("     2   0 3   0\n");
    2531             :   printf("     3   3 0   0\n");
    2532             :   printf("     4   3 3   33     # A special marker for this vertex.\n");
    2533             :   printf("     # Inner square has these vertices:\n");
    2534             :   printf("     5   1 1   0\n");
    2535             :   printf("     6   1 2   0\n");
    2536             :   printf("     7   2 1   0\n");
    2537             :   printf("     8   2 2   0\n");
    2538             :   printf("    # Five segments with boundary markers.\n");
    2539             :   printf("    5 1\n");
    2540             :   printf("     1   1 2   5      # Left side of outer box.\n");
    2541             :   printf("     # Square hole has these segments:\n");
    2542             :   printf("     2   5 7   0\n");
    2543             :   printf("     3   7 8   0\n");
    2544             :   printf("     4   8 6   10\n");
    2545             :   printf("     5   6 5   0\n");
    2546             :   printf("    # One hole in the middle of the inner square.\n");
    2547             :   printf("    1\n");
    2548             :   printf("     1   1.5 1.5\n");
    2549             :   printf("\n");
    2550             :   printf(
    2551             : "  Note that some segments are missing from the outer square, so you must\n");
    2552             :   printf(
    2553             : "  use the `-c' switch.  After `triangle -pqc box.poly', here is the output\n"
    2554             : );
    2555             :   printf(
    2556             : "  file `box.1.node', with twelve vertices.  The last four vertices were\n");
    2557             :   printf(
    2558             : "  added to meet the angle constraint.  Vertices 1, 2, and 9 have markers\n");
    2559             :   printf(
    2560             : "  from segment 1.  Vertices 6 and 8 have markers from segment 4.  All the\n");
    2561             :   printf(
    2562             : "  other vertices but 4 have been marked to indicate that they lie on a\n");
    2563             :   printf("  boundary.\n\n");
    2564             :   printf("    12  2  0  1\n");
    2565             :   printf("       1    0   0      5\n");
    2566             :   printf("       2    0   3      5\n");
    2567             :   printf("       3    3   0      1\n");
    2568             :   printf("       4    3   3     33\n");
    2569             :   printf("       5    1   1      1\n");
    2570             :   printf("       6    1   2     10\n");
    2571             :   printf("       7    2   1      1\n");
    2572             :   printf("       8    2   2     10\n");
    2573             :   printf("       9    0   1.5    5\n");
    2574             :   printf("      10    1.5   0    1\n");
    2575             :   printf("      11    3   1.5    1\n");
    2576             :   printf("      12    1.5   3    1\n");
    2577             :   printf("    # Generated by triangle -pqc box.poly\n");
    2578             :   printf("\n");
    2579             :   printf("  Here is the output file `box.1.ele', with twelve triangles.\n");
    2580             :   printf("\n");
    2581             :   printf("    12  3  0\n");
    2582             :   printf("       1     5   6   9\n");
    2583             :   printf("       2    10   3   7\n");
    2584             :   printf("       3     6   8  12\n");
    2585             :   printf("       4     9   1   5\n");
    2586             :   printf("       5     6   2   9\n");
    2587             :   printf("       6     7   3  11\n");
    2588             :   printf("       7    11   4   8\n");
    2589             :   printf("       8     7   5  10\n");
    2590             :   printf("       9    12   2   6\n");
    2591             :   printf("      10     8   7  11\n");
    2592             :   printf("      11     5   1  10\n");
    2593             :   printf("      12     8   4  12\n");
    2594             :   printf("    # Generated by triangle -pqc box.poly\n\n");
    2595             :   printf(
    2596             : "  Here is the output file `box.1.poly'.  Note that segments have been added\n"
    2597             : );
    2598             :   printf(
    2599             : "  to represent the convex hull, and some segments have been subdivided by\n");
    2600             :   printf(
    2601             : "  newly added vertices.  Note also that <# of vertices> is set to zero to\n");
    2602             :   printf("  indicate that the vertices should be read from the .node file.\n");
    2603             :   printf("\n");
    2604             :   printf("    0  2  0  1\n");
    2605             :   printf("    12  1\n");
    2606             :   printf("       1     1   9     5\n");
    2607             :   printf("       2     5   7     1\n");
    2608             :   printf("       3     8   7     1\n");
    2609             :   printf("       4     6   8    10\n");
    2610             :   printf("       5     5   6     1\n");
    2611             :   printf("       6     3  10     1\n");
    2612             :   printf("       7     4  11     1\n");
    2613             :   printf("       8     2  12     1\n");
    2614             :   printf("       9     9   2     5\n");
    2615             :   printf("      10    10   1     1\n");
    2616             :   printf("      11    11   3     1\n");
    2617             :   printf("      12    12   4     1\n");
    2618             :   printf("    1\n");
    2619             :   printf("       1   1.5 1.5\n");
    2620             :   printf("    # Generated by triangle -pqc box.poly\n");
    2621             :   printf("\n");
    2622             :   printf("Refinement and Area Constraints:\n");
    2623             :   printf("\n");
    2624             :   printf(
    2625             : "  The -r switch causes a mesh (.node and .ele files) to be read and\n");
    2626             :   printf(
    2627             : "  refined.  If the -p switch is also used, a .poly file is read and used to\n"
    2628             : );
    2629             :   printf(
    2630             : "  specify edges that are constrained and cannot be eliminated (although\n");
    2631             :   printf(
    2632             : "  they can be subdivided into smaller edges) by the refinement process.\n");
    2633             :   printf("\n");
    2634             :   printf(
    2635             : "  When you refine a mesh, you generally want to impose tighter constraints.\n"
    2636             : );
    2637             :   printf(
    2638             : "  One way to accomplish this is to use -q with a larger angle, or -a\n");
    2639             :   printf(
    2640             : "  followed by a smaller area than you used to generate the mesh you are\n");
    2641             :   printf(
    2642             : "  refining.  Another way to do this is to create an .area file, which\n");
    2643             :   printf(
    2644             : "  specifies a maximum area for each triangle, and use the -a switch\n");
    2645             :   printf(
    2646             : "  (without a number following).  Each triangle's area constraint is applied\n"
    2647             : );
    2648             :   printf(
    2649             : "  to that triangle.  Area constraints tend to diffuse as the mesh is\n");
    2650             :   printf(
    2651             : "  refined, so if there are large variations in area constraint between\n");
    2652             :   printf(
    2653             : "  adjacent triangles, you may not get the results you want.  In that case,\n"
    2654             : );
    2655             :   printf(
    2656             : "  consider instead using the -u switch and writing a C procedure that\n");
    2657             :   printf("  determines which triangles are too large.\n\n");
    2658             :   printf(
    2659             : "  If you are refining a mesh composed of linear (three-node) elements, the\n"
    2660             : );
    2661             :   printf(
    2662             : "  output mesh contains all the nodes present in the input mesh, in the same\n"
    2663             : );
    2664             :   printf(
    2665             : "  order, with new nodes added at the end of the .node file.  However, the\n");
    2666             :   printf(
    2667             : "  refinement is not hierarchical: there is no guarantee that each output\n");
    2668             :   printf(
    2669             : "  element is contained in a single input element.  Often, an output element\n"
    2670             : );
    2671             :   printf(
    2672             : "  can overlap two or three input elements, and some input edges are not\n");
    2673             :   printf(
    2674             : "  present in the output mesh.  Hence, a sequence of refined meshes forms a\n"
    2675             : );
    2676             :   printf(
    2677             : "  hierarchy of nodes, but not a hierarchy of elements.  If you refine a\n");
    2678             :   printf(
    2679             : "  mesh of higher-order elements, the hierarchical property applies only to\n"
    2680             : );
    2681             :   printf(
    2682             : "  the nodes at the corners of an element; the midpoint nodes on each edge\n");
    2683             :   printf("  are discarded before the mesh is refined.\n\n");
    2684             :   printf(
    2685             : "  Maximum area constraints in .poly files operate differently from those in\n"
    2686             : );
    2687             :   printf(
    2688             : "  .area files.  A maximum area in a .poly file applies to the whole\n");
    2689             :   printf(
    2690             : "  (segment-bounded) region in which a point falls, whereas a maximum area\n");
    2691             :   printf(
    2692             : "  in an .area file applies to only one triangle.  Area constraints in .poly\n"
    2693             : );
    2694             :   printf(
    2695             : "  files are used only when a mesh is first generated, whereas area\n");
    2696             :   printf(
    2697             : "  constraints in .area files are used only to refine an existing mesh, and\n"
    2698             : );
    2699             :   printf(
    2700             : "  are typically based on a posteriori error estimates resulting from a\n");
    2701             :   printf("  finite element simulation on that mesh.\n\n");
    2702             :   printf(
    2703             : "  `triangle -rq25 object.1' reads object.1.node and object.1.ele, then\n");
    2704             :   printf(
    2705             : "  refines the triangulation to enforce a 25 degree minimum angle, and then\n"
    2706             : );
    2707             :   printf(
    2708             : "  writes the refined triangulation to object.2.node and object.2.ele.\n");
    2709             :   printf("\n");
    2710             :   printf(
    2711             : "  `triangle -rpaa6.2 z.3' reads z.3.node, z.3.ele, z.3.poly, and z.3.area.\n"
    2712             : );
    2713             :   printf(
    2714             : "  After reconstructing the mesh and its subsegments, Triangle refines the\n");
    2715             :   printf(
    2716             : "  mesh so that no triangle has area greater than 6.2, and furthermore the\n");
    2717             :   printf(
    2718             : "  triangles satisfy the maximum area constraints in z.3.area.  No angle\n");
    2719             :   printf(
    2720             : "  bound is imposed at all.  The output is written to z.4.node, z.4.ele, and\n"
    2721             : );
    2722             :   printf("  z.4.poly.\n\n");
    2723             :   printf(
    2724             : "  The sequence `triangle -qa1 x', `triangle -rqa.3 x.1', `triangle -rqa.1\n");
    2725             :   printf(
    2726             : "  x.2' creates a sequence of successively finer meshes x.1, x.2, and x.3,\n");
    2727             :   printf("  suitable for multigrid.\n\n");
    2728             :   printf("Convex Hulls and Mesh Boundaries:\n\n");
    2729             :   printf(
    2730             : "  If the input is a vertex set (not a PSLG), Triangle produces its convex\n");
    2731             :   printf(
    2732             : "  hull as a by-product in the output .poly file if you use the -c switch.\n");
    2733             :   printf(
    2734             : "  There are faster algorithms for finding a two-dimensional convex hull\n");
    2735             :   printf("  than triangulation, of course, but this one comes for free.\n\n");
    2736             :   printf(
    2737             : "  If the input is an unconstrained mesh (you are using the -r switch but\n");
    2738             :   printf(
    2739             : "  not the -p switch), Triangle produces a list of its boundary edges\n");
    2740             :   printf(
    2741             : "  (including hole boundaries) as a by-product when you use the -c switch.\n");
    2742             :   printf(
    2743             : "  If you also use the -p switch, the output .poly file contains all the\n");
    2744             :   printf("  segments from the input .poly file as well.\n\n");
    2745             :   printf("Voronoi Diagrams:\n\n");
    2746             :   printf(
    2747             : "  The -v switch produces a Voronoi diagram, in files suffixed .v.node and\n");
    2748             :   printf(
    2749             : "  .v.edge.  For example, `triangle -v points' reads points.node, produces\n");
    2750             :   printf(
    2751             : "  its Delaunay triangulation in points.1.node and points.1.ele, and\n");
    2752             :   printf(
    2753             : "  produces its Voronoi diagram in points.1.v.node and points.1.v.edge.  The\n"
    2754             : );
    2755             :   printf(
    2756             : "  .v.node file contains a list of all Voronoi vertices, and the .v.edge\n");
    2757             :   printf(
    2758             : "  file contains a list of all Voronoi edges, some of which may be infinite\n"
    2759             : );
    2760             :   printf(
    2761             : "  rays.  (The choice of filenames makes it easy to run the set of Voronoi\n");
    2762             :   printf("  vertices through Triangle, if so desired.)\n\n");
    2763             :   printf(
    2764             : "  This implementation does not use exact arithmetic to compute the Voronoi\n"
    2765             : );
    2766             :   printf(
    2767             : "  vertices, and does not check whether neighboring vertices are identical.\n"
    2768             : );
    2769             :   printf(
    2770             : "  Be forewarned that if the Delaunay triangulation is degenerate or\n");
    2771             :   printf(
    2772             : "  near-degenerate, the Voronoi diagram may have duplicate vertices or\n");
    2773             :   printf("  crossing edges.\n\n");
    2774             :   printf(
    2775             : "  The result is a valid Voronoi diagram only if Triangle's output is a true\n"
    2776             : );
    2777             :   printf(
    2778             : "  Delaunay triangulation.  The Voronoi output is usually meaningless (and\n");
    2779             :   printf(
    2780             : "  may contain crossing edges and other pathology) if the output is a CDT or\n"
    2781             : );
    2782             :   printf(
    2783             : "  CCDT, or if it has holes or concavities.  If the triangulated domain is\n");
    2784             :   printf(
    2785             : "  convex and has no holes, you can use -D switch to force Triangle to\n");
    2786             :   printf(
    2787             : "  construct a conforming Delaunay triangulation instead of a CCDT, so the\n");
    2788             :   printf("  Voronoi diagram will be valid.\n\n");
    2789             :   printf("Mesh Topology:\n\n");
    2790             :   printf(
    2791             : "  You may wish to know which triangles are adjacent to a certain Delaunay\n");
    2792             :   printf(
    2793             : "  edge in an .edge file, which Voronoi cells are adjacent to a certain\n");
    2794             :   printf(
    2795             : "  Voronoi edge in a .v.edge file, or which Voronoi cells are adjacent to\n");
    2796             :   printf(
    2797             : "  each other.  All of this information can be found by cross-referencing\n");
    2798             :   printf(
    2799             : "  output files with the recollection that the Delaunay triangulation and\n");
    2800             :   printf("  the Voronoi diagram are planar duals.\n\n");
    2801             :   printf(
    2802             : "  Specifically, edge i of an .edge file is the dual of Voronoi edge i of\n");
    2803             :   printf(
    2804             : "  the corresponding .v.edge file, and is rotated 90 degrees counterclock-\n");
    2805             :   printf(
    2806             : "  wise from the Voronoi edge.  Triangle j of an .ele file is the dual of\n");
    2807             :   printf(
    2808             : "  vertex j of the corresponding .v.node file.  Voronoi cell k is the dual\n");
    2809             :   printf("  of vertex k of the corresponding .node file.\n\n");
    2810             :   printf(
    2811             : "  Hence, to find the triangles adjacent to a Delaunay edge, look at the\n");
    2812             :   printf(
    2813             : "  vertices of the corresponding Voronoi edge.  If the endpoints of a\n");
    2814             :   printf(
    2815             : "  Voronoi edge are Voronoi vertices 2 and 6 respectively, then triangles 2\n"
    2816             : );
    2817             :   printf(
    2818             : "  and 6 adjoin the left and right sides of the corresponding Delaunay edge,\n"
    2819             : );
    2820             :   printf(
    2821             : "  respectively.  To find the Voronoi cells adjacent to a Voronoi edge, look\n"
    2822             : );
    2823             :   printf(
    2824             : "  at the endpoints of the corresponding Delaunay edge.  If the endpoints of\n"
    2825             : );
    2826             :   printf(
    2827             : "  a Delaunay edge are input vertices 7 and 12, then Voronoi cells 7 and 12\n"
    2828             : );
    2829             :   printf(
    2830             : "  adjoin the right and left sides of the corresponding Voronoi edge,\n");
    2831             :   printf(
    2832             : "  respectively.  To find which Voronoi cells are adjacent to each other,\n");
    2833             :   printf("  just read the list of Delaunay edges.\n\n");
    2834             :   printf(
    2835             : "  Triangle does not write a list of the edges adjoining each Voronoi cell,\n"
    2836             : );
    2837             :   printf(
    2838             : "  but you can reconstructed it straightforwardly.  For instance, to find\n");
    2839             :   printf(
    2840             : "  all the edges of Voronoi cell 1, search the output .edge file for every\n");
    2841             :   printf(
    2842             : "  edge that has input vertex 1 as an endpoint.  The corresponding dual\n");
    2843             :   printf(
    2844             : "  edges in the output .v.edge file form the boundary of Voronoi cell 1.\n");
    2845             :   printf("\n");
    2846             :   printf(
    2847             : "  For each Voronoi vertex, the .neigh file gives a list of the three\n");
    2848             :   printf(
    2849             : "  Voronoi vertices attached to it.  You might find this more convenient\n");
    2850             :   printf("  than the .v.edge file.\n\n");
    2851             :   printf("Quadratic Elements:\n\n");
    2852             :   printf(
    2853             : "  Triangle generates meshes with subparametric quadratic elements if the\n");
    2854             :   printf(
    2855             : "  -o2 switch is specified.  Quadratic elements have six nodes per element,\n"
    2856             : );
    2857             :   printf(
    2858             : "  rather than three.  `Subparametric' means that the edges of the triangles\n"
    2859             : );
    2860             :   printf(
    2861             : "  are always straight, so that subparametric quadratic elements are\n");
    2862             :   printf(
    2863             : "  geometrically identical to linear elements, even though they can be used\n"
    2864             : );
    2865             :   printf(
    2866             : "  with quadratic interpolating functions.  The three extra nodes of an\n");
    2867             :   printf(
    2868             : "  element fall at the midpoints of the three edges, with the fourth, fifth,\n"
    2869             : );
    2870             :   printf(
    2871             : "  and sixth nodes appearing opposite the first, second, and third corners\n");
    2872             :   printf("  respectively.\n\n");
    2873             :   printf("Domains with Small Angles:\n\n");
    2874             :   printf(
    2875             : "  If two input segments adjoin each other at a small angle, clearly the -q\n"
    2876             : );
    2877             :   printf(
    2878             : "  switch cannot remove the small angle.  Moreover, Triangle may have no\n");
    2879             :   printf(
    2880             : "  choice but to generate additional triangles whose smallest angles are\n");
    2881             :   printf(
    2882             : "  smaller than the specified bound.  However, these triangles only appear\n");
    2883             :   printf(
    2884             : "  between input segments separated by small angles.  Moreover, if you\n");
    2885             :   printf(
    2886             : "  request a minimum angle of theta degrees, Triangle will generally produce\n"
    2887             : );
    2888             :   printf(
    2889             : "  no angle larger than 180 - 2 theta, even if it is forced to compromise on\n"
    2890             : );
    2891             :   printf("  the minimum angle.\n\n");
    2892             :   printf("Statistics:\n\n");
    2893             :   printf(
    2894             : "  After generating a mesh, Triangle prints a count of entities in the\n");
    2895             :   printf(
    2896             : "  output mesh, including the number of vertices, triangles, edges, exterior\n"
    2897             : );
    2898             :   printf(
    2899             : "  boundary edges (i.e. subsegments on the boundary of the triangulation,\n");
    2900             :   printf(
    2901             : "  including hole boundaries), interior boundary edges (i.e. subsegments of\n"
    2902             : );
    2903             :   printf(
    2904             : "  input segments not on the boundary), and total subsegments.  If you've\n");
    2905             :   printf(
    2906             : "  forgotten the statistics for an existing mesh, run Triangle on that mesh\n"
    2907             : );
    2908             :   printf(
    2909             : "  with the -rNEP switches to read the mesh and print the statistics without\n"
    2910             : );
    2911             :   printf(
    2912             : "  writing any files.  Use -rpNEP if you've got a .poly file for the mesh.\n");
    2913             :   printf("\n");
    2914             :   printf(
    2915             : "  The -V switch produces extended statistics, including a rough estimate\n");
    2916             :   printf(
    2917             : "  of memory use, the number of calls to geometric predicates, and\n");
    2918             :   printf(
    2919             : "  histograms of the angles and the aspect ratios of the triangles in the\n");
    2920             :   printf("  mesh.\n\n");
    2921             :   printf("Exact Arithmetic:\n\n");
    2922             :   printf(
    2923             : "  Triangle uses adaptive exact arithmetic to perform what computational\n");
    2924             :   printf(
    2925             : "  geometers call the `orientation' and `incircle' tests.  If the floating-\n"
    2926             : );
    2927             :   printf(
    2928             : "  point arithmetic of your machine conforms to the IEEE 754 standard (as\n");
    2929             :   printf(
    2930             : "  most workstations do), and does not use extended precision internal\n");
    2931             :   printf(
    2932             : "  floating-point registers, then your output is guaranteed to be an\n");
    2933             :   printf(
    2934             : "  absolutely true Delaunay or constrained Delaunay triangulation, roundoff\n"
    2935             : );
    2936             :   printf(
    2937             : "  error notwithstanding.  The word `adaptive' implies that these arithmetic\n"
    2938             : );
    2939             :   printf(
    2940             : "  routines compute the result only to the precision necessary to guarantee\n"
    2941             : );
    2942             :   printf(
    2943             : "  correctness, so they are usually nearly as fast as their approximate\n");
    2944             :   printf("  counterparts.\n\n");
    2945             :   printf(
    2946             : "  May CPUs, including Intel x86 processors, have extended precision\n");
    2947             :   printf(
    2948             : "  floating-point registers.  These must be reconfigured so their precision\n"
    2949             : );
    2950             :   printf(
    2951             : "  is reduced to memory precision.  Triangle does this if it is compiled\n");
    2952             :   printf("  correctly.  See the makefile for details.\n\n");
    2953             :   printf(
    2954             : "  The exact tests can be disabled with the -X switch.  On most inputs, this\n"
    2955             : );
    2956             :   printf(
    2957             : "  switch reduces the computation time by about eight percent--it's not\n");
    2958             :   printf(
    2959             : "  worth the risk.  There are rare difficult inputs (having many collinear\n");
    2960             :   printf(
    2961             : "  and cocircular vertices), however, for which the difference in speed\n");
    2962             :   printf(
    2963             : "  could be a factor of two.  Be forewarned that these are precisely the\n");
    2964             :   printf(
    2965             : "  inputs most likely to cause errors if you use the -X switch.  Hence, the\n"
    2966             : );
    2967             :   printf("  -X switch is not recommended.\n\n");
    2968             :   printf(
    2969             : "  Unfortunately, the exact tests don't solve every numerical problem.\n");
    2970             :   printf(
    2971             : "  Exact arithmetic is not used to compute the positions of new vertices,\n");
    2972             :   printf(
    2973             : "  because the bit complexity of vertex coordinates would grow without\n");
    2974             :   printf(
    2975             : "  bound.  Hence, segment intersections aren't computed exactly; in very\n");
    2976             :   printf(
    2977             : "  unusual cases, roundoff error in computing an intersection point might\n");
    2978             :   printf(
    2979             : "  actually lead to an inverted triangle and an invalid triangulation.\n");
    2980             :   printf(
    2981             : "  (This is one reason to specify your own intersection points in your .poly\n"
    2982             : );
    2983             :   printf(
    2984             : "  files.)  Similarly, exact arithmetic is not used to compute the vertices\n"
    2985             : );
    2986             :   printf("  of the Voronoi diagram.\n\n");
    2987             :   printf(
    2988             : "  Another pair of problems not solved by the exact arithmetic routines is\n");
    2989             :   printf(
    2990             : "  underflow and overflow.  If Triangle is compiled for double precision\n");
    2991             :   printf(
    2992             : "  arithmetic, I believe that Triangle's geometric predicates work correctly\n"
    2993             : );
    2994             :   printf(
    2995             : "  if the exponent of every input coordinate falls in the range [-148, 201].\n"
    2996             : );
    2997             :   printf(
    2998             : "  Underflow can silently prevent the orientation and incircle tests from\n");
    2999             :   printf(
    3000             : "  being performed exactly, while overflow typically causes a floating\n");
    3001             :   printf("  exception.\n\n");
    3002             :   printf("Calling Triangle from Another Program:\n\n");
    3003             :   printf("  Read the file triangle.h for details.\n\n");
    3004             :   printf("Troubleshooting:\n\n");
    3005             :   printf("  Please read this section before mailing me bugs.\n\n");
    3006             :   printf("  `My output mesh has no triangles!'\n\n");
    3007             :   printf(
    3008             : "    If you're using a PSLG, you've probably failed to specify a proper set\n"
    3009             : );
    3010             :   printf(
    3011             : "    of bounding segments, or forgotten to use the -c switch.  Or you may\n");
    3012             :   printf(
    3013             : "    have placed a hole badly, thereby eating all your triangles.  To test\n");
    3014             :   printf("    these possibilities, try again with the -c and -O switches.\n");
    3015             :   printf(
    3016             : "    Alternatively, all your input vertices may be collinear, in which case\n"
    3017             : );
    3018             :   printf("    you can hardly expect to triangulate them.\n\n");
    3019             :   printf("  `Triangle doesn't terminate, or just crashes.'\n\n");
    3020             :   printf(
    3021             : "    Bad things can happen when triangles get so small that the distance\n");
    3022             :   printf(
    3023             : "    between their vertices isn't much larger than the precision of your\n");
    3024             :   printf(
    3025             : "    machine's arithmetic.  If you've compiled Triangle for single-precision\n"
    3026             : );
    3027             :   printf(
    3028             : "    arithmetic, you might do better by recompiling it for double-precision.\n"
    3029             : );
    3030             :   printf(
    3031             : "    Then again, you might just have to settle for more lenient constraints\n"
    3032             : );
    3033             :   printf(
    3034             : "    on the minimum angle and the maximum area than you had planned.\n");
    3035             :   printf("\n");
    3036             :   printf(
    3037             : "    You can minimize precision problems by ensuring that the origin lies\n");
    3038             :   printf(
    3039             : "    inside your vertex set, or even inside the densest part of your\n");
    3040             :   printf(
    3041             : "    mesh.  If you're triangulating an object whose x-coordinates all fall\n");
    3042             :   printf(
    3043             : "    between 6247133 and 6247134, you're not leaving much floating-point\n");
    3044             :   printf("    precision for Triangle to work with.\n\n");
    3045             :   printf(
    3046             : "    Precision problems can occur covertly if the input PSLG contains two\n");
    3047             :   printf(
    3048             : "    segments that meet (or intersect) at an extremely small angle, or if\n");
    3049             :   printf(
    3050             : "    such an angle is introduced by the -c switch.  If you don't realize\n");
    3051             :   printf(
    3052             : "    that a tiny angle is being formed, you might never discover why\n");
    3053             :   printf(
    3054             : "    Triangle is crashing.  To check for this possibility, use the -S switch\n"
    3055             : );
    3056             :   printf(
    3057             : "    (with an appropriate limit on the number of Steiner points, found by\n");
    3058             :   printf(
    3059             : "    trial-and-error) to stop Triangle early, and view the output .poly file\n"
    3060             : );
    3061             :   printf(
    3062             : "    with Show Me (described below).  Look carefully for regions where dense\n"
    3063             : );
    3064             :   printf(
    3065             : "    clusters of vertices are forming and for small angles between segments.\n"
    3066             : );
    3067             :   printf(
    3068             : "    Zoom in closely, as such segments might look like a single segment from\n"
    3069             : );
    3070             :   printf("    a distance.\n\n");
    3071             :   printf(
    3072             : "    If some of the input values are too large, Triangle may suffer a\n");
    3073             :   printf(
    3074             : "    floating exception due to overflow when attempting to perform an\n");
    3075             :   printf(
    3076             : "    orientation or incircle test.  (Read the section on exact arithmetic\n");
    3077             :   printf(
    3078             : "    above.)  Again, I recommend compiling Triangle for double (rather\n");
    3079             :   printf("    than single) precision arithmetic.\n\n");
    3080             :   printf(
    3081             : "    Unexpected problems can arise if you use quality meshing (-q, -a, or\n");
    3082             :   printf(
    3083             : "    -u) with an input that is not segment-bounded--that is, if your input\n");
    3084             :   printf(
    3085             : "    is a vertex set, or you're using the -c switch.  If the convex hull of\n"
    3086             : );
    3087             :   printf(
    3088             : "    your input vertices has collinear vertices on its boundary, an input\n");
    3089             :   printf(
    3090             : "    vertex that you think lies on the convex hull might actually lie just\n");
    3091             :   printf(
    3092             : "    inside the convex hull.  If so, the vertex and the nearby convex hull\n");
    3093             :   printf(
    3094             : "    edge form an extremely thin triangle.  When Triangle tries to refine\n");
    3095             :   printf(
    3096             : "    the mesh to enforce angle and area constraints, Triangle might generate\n"
    3097             : );
    3098             :   printf(
    3099             : "    extremely tiny triangles, or it might fail because of insufficient\n");
    3100             :   printf("    floating-point precision.\n\n");
    3101             :   printf(
    3102             : "  `The numbering of the output vertices doesn't match the input vertices.'\n"
    3103             : );
    3104             :   printf("\n");
    3105             :   printf(
    3106             : "    You may have had duplicate input vertices, or you may have eaten some\n");
    3107             :   printf(
    3108             : "    of your input vertices with a hole, or by placing them outside the area\n"
    3109             : );
    3110             :   printf(
    3111             : "    enclosed by segments.  In any case, you can solve the problem by not\n");
    3112             :   printf("    using the -j switch.\n\n");
    3113             :   printf(
    3114             : "  `Triangle executes without incident, but when I look at the resulting\n");
    3115             :   printf(
    3116             : "  mesh, it has overlapping triangles or other geometric inconsistencies.'\n");
    3117             :   printf("\n");
    3118             :   printf(
    3119             : "    If you select the -X switch, Triangle occasionally makes mistakes due\n");
    3120             :   printf(
    3121             : "    to floating-point roundoff error.  Although these errors are rare,\n");
    3122             :   printf(
    3123             : "    don't use the -X switch.  If you still have problems, please report the\n"
    3124             : );
    3125             :   printf("    bug.\n\n");
    3126             :   printf(
    3127             : "  `Triangle executes without incident, but when I look at the resulting\n");
    3128             :   printf("  Voronoi diagram, it has overlapping edges or other geometric\n");
    3129             :   printf("  inconsistencies.'\n");
    3130             :   printf("\n");
    3131             :   printf(
    3132             : "    If your input is a PSLG (-p), you can only expect a meaningful Voronoi\n"
    3133             : );
    3134             :   printf(
    3135             : "    diagram if the domain you are triangulating is convex and free of\n");
    3136             :   printf(
    3137             : "    holes, and you use the -D switch to construct a conforming Delaunay\n");
    3138             :   printf("    triangulation (instead of a CDT or CCDT).\n\n");
    3139             :   printf(
    3140             : "  Strange things can happen if you've taken liberties with your PSLG.  Do\n");
    3141             :   printf(
    3142             : "  you have a vertex lying in the middle of a segment?  Triangle sometimes\n");
    3143             :   printf(
    3144             : "  copes poorly with that sort of thing.  Do you want to lay out a collinear\n"
    3145             : );
    3146             :   printf(
    3147             : "  row of evenly spaced, segment-connected vertices?  Have you simply\n");
    3148             :   printf(
    3149             : "  defined one ptrdiff_t  segment connecting the leftmost vertex to the rightmost\n"
    3150             : );
    3151             :   printf(
    3152             : "  vertex, and a bunch of vertices lying along it?  This method occasionally\n"
    3153             : );
    3154             :   printf(
    3155             : "  works, especially with horizontal and vertical lines, but often it\n");
    3156             :   printf(
    3157             : "  doesn't, and you'll have to connect each adjacent pair of vertices with a\n"
    3158             : );
    3159             :   printf("  separate segment.  If you don't like it, tough.\n\n");
    3160             :   printf(
    3161             : "  Furthermore, if you have segments that intersect other than at their\n");
    3162             :   printf(
    3163             : "  endpoints, try not to let the intersections fall extremely close to PSLG\n"
    3164             : );
    3165             :   printf("  vertices or each other.\n\n");
    3166             :   printf(
    3167             : "  If you have problems refining a triangulation not produced by Triangle:\n");
    3168             :   printf(
    3169             : "  Are you sure the triangulation is geometrically valid?  Is it formatted\n");
    3170             :   printf(
    3171             : "  correctly for Triangle?  Are the triangles all listed so the first three\n"
    3172             : );
    3173             :   printf(
    3174             : "  vertices are their corners in counterclockwise order?  Are all of the\n");
    3175             :   printf(
    3176             : "  triangles constrained Delaunay?  Triangle's Delaunay refinement algorithm\n"
    3177             : );
    3178             :   printf("  assumes that it starts with a CDT.\n\n");
    3179             :   printf("Show Me:\n\n");
    3180             :   printf(
    3181             : "  Triangle comes with a separate program named `Show Me', whose primary\n");

    3183             : "  purpose is to draw meshes on your screen or in PostScript.  Its secondary\n"
    3184             : );
    3185             :   printf(

    3187             :   printf(
    3188             : "  thoroughly than Triangle does.  Unlike Triangle, Show Me requires that\n");
    3189             :   printf(
    3190             : "  you have the X Windows system.  Sorry, Microsoft Windows users.\n");
    3191             :   printf("\n");
    3192             :   printf("Triangle on the Web:\n");
    3193             :   printf("\n");

    3197             :   printf("\n");
    3198             :   printf("A Brief Plea:\n");
    3199             :   printf("\n");
    3200             :   printf(
    3201             : "  If you use Triangle, and especially if you use it to accomplish real\n");
    3202             :   printf(
    3203             : "  work, I would like very much to hear from you.  A short letter or email\n");
    3204             :   printf(

    3209             : );

    3593             :     strcpy(b->vedgefilename, b->innodefilename);

    3595             :     strcpy(b->offfilename, b->innodefilename);

    3599             :     strcat(b->vnodefilename, ".v.node");
    3600             :     strcat(b->vedgefilename, ".v.edge");
    3601             :     strcat(b->neighborfilename, ".neigh");
    3602             :     strcat(b->offfilename, ".off");
    3603             :   } else if (increment == 0) {
    3604             :     strcpy(b->outnodefilename, b->innodefilename);
    3605             :     strcpy(b->outpolyfilename, b->innodefilename);
    3606             :     strcpy(b->outelefilename, b->innodefilename);
    3607             :     strcpy(b->edgefilename, b->innodefilename);
    3608             :     strcpy(b->vnodefilename, b->innodefilename);
    3609             :     strcpy(b->vedgefilename, b->innodefilename);
    3610             :     strcpy(b->neighborfilename, b->innodefilename);
    3611             :     strcpy(b->offfilename, b->innodefilename);
    3612             :     strcat(b->outnodefilename, ".1.node");
    3613             :     strcat(b->outpolyfilename, ".1.poly");
    3614             :     strcat(b->outelefilename, ".1.ele");

    3618             :     strcat(b->neighborfilename, ".1.neigh");

    3658             : /*  printtriangle()   Print out the details of an oriented triangle.         */
    3659             : /*                                                                           */
    3660             : /*  I originally wrote this procedure to simplify debugging; it can be       */
    3661             : /*  called directly from the debugger, and presents information about an     */
    3662             : /*  oriented triangle in digestible form.  It's also used when the           */
    3663             : /*  highest level of verbosity (`-VVV') is specified.                        */

    3795             :   else

    3799           0 :   sdest(*s, printvertex);
    3800           0 :   if (printvertex == (vertex) NULL)
    3801           0 :     printf("    Dest  [%d] = NULL\n", 3 - s->ssorient);
    3802             :   else
